div.head: ACT I .

stage.stage: A sitting-room in the only hotel at a small seaside resort in Essex . Old-fashioned Victorian furniture , producing a picturesque general effect . Some modern touch , such as a framed coloured advertisement of pneumatic tyres .

Door , R ., leading to hall , principal entrance , and kitchen . Door , L ., leading through a porch to the garden . A large window , divided into three portions by stonework , at the back : the panes are small ; one of these portions is open , the others are closed .
Through the window can be seen a view of the garden , and the sea in the distance . The fireplace is not seen .
CEDRIC and FLORA are seated at either side of a tea-table .

div.stage: TIME : Afternoon in June . Sunshine .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Another cup ?CEDRIC , looking at her , makes no reply .Cedric ! Another cup ?with a touch of very good-humoured impatience

div.stage: CEDRIC rises , goes round the table to her , takes hold of her , and kisses her .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Standing over her , she looking up at him .I 've been wanting to do that for about thirty solid minutes .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Then why did n't you , my poor boy ?CEDRIC gives a gesture to show that he does n't know whyInstead of keeping us both waiting like that !Reflective .And yet it 's barely three hours since you kissed me in the vestry !

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Vestry be dashed ! And here 's another thing I 've been wanting to dohe carefully kisses her ear

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: My ear !

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Precisely , your ear ! Strange !... And I can tell you something even stranger . Shall I ?She nods .When I 'm standing over you I feel as if I should like to kill you ! Yes , really , Fluff ! It takes me all of a sudden ! You know — when you lean out of a high balcony and you feel you must jump — well , it 's that sort of a feeling .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: What particular kind of homicide ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Oh !at a lossa kind of a fierce crushing .She smiles .You think it 's justifiable ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I do n't mind so long as I know my risks .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: After staring at her , with a convinced air .We shall get on together all right !

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Yes , I think we 're doing rather well so far , consideringturning the ring on his finger

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Considering what ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Considering how nervous we both are , naturallydrops his hand

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Moving away . Half to himself .Yes , and we shall keep getting more nervous !

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Resuming exactly the same matter-of-fact tone as when she first put the question .Another cup ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Similar tone .How many have I had ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I do n't know , dear .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: I 've had enough , then .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Well , about our programme . Suppose we settle it a bit .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Yes , let 's .Sits down .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I do think it was a lovely idea to start off without any programme at all ! Heaven itself could n't say where we sha n't be this time next week !

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Well , subject to your approval , I do n't mind informing heaven that anyhow we sha n't be here .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Tired of this place — already ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: On the contrary ! But it 's too small to hold a couple that have just walked out of a vestry . One hotel , one flagstaff , one boat , one sea . No pier , no tea-shop , no concert , and very probably no moon .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Extraordinary how even three hours of married life will change a man ! You always used to be rather keen on quietness , solitude , old flannel suits , and so on .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Now look here , Fluff ! This honeymoon programme is important . Er —hesitates

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Nods .Let 's talk as man to man .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: The fact is I 've always had a very distinct theory about honeymoons . Far from the madding crowd is a mistake on a honeymoon .... Solitude ! Wherever you are , if you 're on a honeymoon , you 'll get quite as much solitude as is good for you every twenty-four hours . Constant change and distraction — that 's what wants arranging for . Solitude will arrange itself .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I did n't expect this from you , dear .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Hastily , apologetic .Simply a theory ! I 've had no practical experience , and I 'm perfectly ready to sit at your feet in the matter . Honestly , I do n't care a straw . I may be wrong , and if you ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Solemnly .You are n't wrong ! You 're quite fearfully right !

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: After staring at her with a convinced air .We shall get on together — that 's a bedrock certainty ! Now this place ought to be excellent for a beginning , but I should imagine that about a couple of days of it would do us .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I never suspected — no , really , I never did suspect — that any man could have as much common-sense , beforehand , as you have , Cedric . Not to speak of courage !

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Cheek , you mean . But then , of course , I am supposed to have a bit of nerve . Well , that 's settled . We are to travel , then .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: The point is , where ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Where would you like ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Radiantly .Anywhere .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: What about Paris ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Oh , not Paris .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: We should be simply mobbed . My dearest boy , have you ever heard speak of the simplicity of genius ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: I seem to have read about it somewhere , perhaps in the ladies ’ papers .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Well , you wo n't understand it , because you 've got it — acutely .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: And here all these years I 've been taking myself for rather a crafty person !

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Do you know how many times I 've counted your portrait in the weeklies this year ? One hundred and forty-six ! And that 's not reckoning the pictures where your aeroplane 's so high up that you only look like a fly in a mouse-trap .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: In my simple mind I 'd always thought that the surest way never to be recognised in the street was to have your portrait in the papers .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: And then there 's your likeness to your mother ! A hundred and fifty-one thousand copies of your dear mother 's last novel sold up to yesterday — so I saw in the “ Telegraph . ” And then her new novel out to-day !

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: I 'm not suggesting that we should camp out in Piccadilly for our honeymoon , my dove and my love ; I said Paris .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: All London will be in Paris .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: What — next week ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Every week . Excuse me asking a pointed question , dearest , but have you ever been to Paris — I mean , since the flood ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Yes . My knowledge of the unwieldy goods department of the big railway stations is probably matchless .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Well , if you 'd stepped outside the stations you 'd know that Paris is now exclusively inhabited by nice respectable people from London and nice respectable people from Arizona ; and when they are n't cricking their necks to look at aeroplanes , they 're improving their minds with your dear mother 's latest novel .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Mock serious .Will you believe me — I 'd no notion of this at all !

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I tell you what — I would n't mind going to Paris under an assumed name .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Oh , no !

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Why not ? It would be amusing .

lg.l: I do n't see myself travelling under a false name . I suppose
I am too English .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Well , I do n't see myself in a Paris hotel as the bride of the most celebrated English aviator , and the daughter-in-law of the most celebrated English lady-novelist . I do not !With a characteristic gesture .Mobbed is n't the word for what we should be .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Gazing at her .You must have noticed that I 'm not what you 'd call gushing . I 've known myself go for a month without using a single superlative ; but really , my most dear girl , my Fluffiest , when you strike an attitude like that , you 're more marvellously and ineffably adorable than ever . Your beauty , your charm , your enormous slap-upness —changing his tone— Well , ecstasy is not my line .... I only said Paris because the mater asked me if I thought we should be going there , and I told her it was possible .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Will she be there ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: No , no ! Only , if we should happen to go there , she wanted me to count the panes of glass in a lamp-post on the Alexander III . bridge . One of her realistic details , you know . I expect she 's got her hero staring absently up at that lamp-post — after an indiscreet evening .... She may be depending on me .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: But surely that is n't a reason why we should go to Paris ! Your dear mother might have wanted to know the number of ribs in the umbrella of the King of Siam — should we have had to book to Bangkok ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: I was only ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Husband , I must tell you something about your mother . I 've kept it a secret from you . Do you know what made her give up her terrific scheme of our being married in the cathedral by the Bishop , surrounded by the press of Europe ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: I thought our angel-tongues persuaded her out of it .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Not at all . A threat did it . I dropped in on her one day for a little private chat while you were at Blackpool . She was just going to arrange with the Bishop . I told her confidentially — but of course nicely — that if she would n't agree to us being married by a curate at Chelmsford , with nobody but her and your father and Charlie present , and nothing whatever in the papers for at least a fortnight , then I should insist on being married at a registry office .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: The deuce you did ! What did she say ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: She merely said : “ Of course your wish is our law , Mrs. Lloyd . ” But the next day she was calling me “ Flora ” again .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: The mater folded up like that ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: There !Laughing .Listen to your own tone , dearest . Naturally she folded up . She only needs proper treatment .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Well , I had a bit of a stir with her when I decided to give up my amateur status ; but I must say as a rule I get on very well with the mater .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: So do I . It 's because I get on so well with her that we had a curate to-day instead of the Bishop . Rather a jolly curate , did n't you think ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Struck me as a queer lot .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Of course they 're all queer . I liked him because when he asked me to sign my name he did n't sayimitating the snigger of a curate“ for the last time . ” They always do , you know . It 's almost part of the service , for them . And if he had said it , I do believe I should have screamed .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: I say , Fluff , why after hiding this secret for several weeks — it 's practically a double life that you 've been leading — why do you reveal it just at this particular moment ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Oh — sheer caprice , my dearest ! It just popped into my head .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Somewhat troubled and awkward .So your notion is that the mater 's moral empire over her family and the British public might be checked without grave loss of life , eh ?

lg.l: Cedric !
lg.stage: CEDRIC looks at her , arrested and questioning .
lg.l: What 's the rarest thing in the world ? Quick ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Common-sense , of course .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Oh ! Good ! I was afraid you might say a well-cooked potato .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: You ought to know me better than that .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: But , Cedric , it 's only now that we 're beginning to make each other 's acquaintance .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: That 's true ! But how did you know that common-sense is the rarest thing in the world ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Because I 've got so very little of it myself . But even a very little will go a long way . Now , have I told you that our marriage is n't going to be like ordinary marriages — I mean , really ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Well , you have n't exactly told me , but you 've allowed me to suspect the fact .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Most marriages , and especially most honeymoons , are third-rate simply because the people concerned in them do n't bring their bit of common-sense to bear on the problems that aremock platform manner— er — continually arising .Laughing .I intend to keep my bit of common-sense healthy by constant exercise . Common-sense , steadily applied , will solve any problem .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Emphatically .Any !After a pause .Always provided ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Surprised .Always provided ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: My dear , in this outpouring of wisdom I , too , must have my share . Common-sense will solve any problem — any !— always provided it is employed simultaneously with politeness . During a long and varied career as a bachelor , dear spousemock platform manner, I have noticed that marriage is usually the death of politeness between a man and a woman . I have noticed that the stronger the passion the weaker the manners . Now , my theory is that politeness , instead of decreasing with intimacy — should increase ! And when I say “ politeness ” I mean common , superficial politeness . I do n't mean the deep-down sort of thing that you can only detect with a divining-rod .... Pardon , you were saying ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Cedric !Impulsively rushes to him and kisses him .How right you are ! It 's exactly what I 've been thinking for years . Now , as to common-sense and the programme . It would be against common-sense for us to begin by annoying your mother . If you really do think your mother would be in the least upset by our not going to Paris , naturally I shall be delighted to go . We could stop just long enough to inspect the lamp-post — and then off again .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Oh , no ! Oh , no ! Of course she wo n't be upset !

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: That 's settled , then . Do you know I 've had the tiniest idea of going to Ostend , and then taking the Orient express to Buda-Pesth ? I 'm dying to see Hungary , simply dying .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: My dearest , your life shall be saved regardless of cost .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I do want an expensive honeymoon . Not because I 'm extravagant , but because a honeymoon is a solemn , important thing .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: A symbol .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: A symbol . And it ought to be done — well , adequately .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Nineteen thousand pounds odd of mine is now on deposit at my bank — all honestly taken by me out of the pockets of ratepayers of various important towns in less than a year . And when that 's gone I can always get more at about the same rate , as you know .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Cedric ! There is to be no flying during our honeymoon ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Certainly not !

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: And it is to last a full month , naturally .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: A full calendar month — with no address for letters .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Sigh of ecstatic anticipation .Two or three days , you said , here ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Yes , do n't you think it 's enough ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Oh ! quite . We shall be gone before anybody 's had time to guess —breaking offDearest , do n't you think we came into the hotel rather well ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Fine . No one could suspect that we had n't been born married . I was proud of both of us .

div.stage: Enter GASTON , R .

sp.speaker: GASTON
sp.p: Shall I clear the table ?Beginning to do so before receiving permission .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Yes .FLORA and CEDRIC rise .

sp.speaker: GASTON
sp.p: With a cheerful air , quite unconscious of his impudent manner .I suppose you stay here long time ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Determined to snub the waiter .Really !

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: GASTON
sp.p: Oh ! honeymoon . Dull place . Fresh married English people demand generally dull place .

div.stage: FLORA collapses and exit hurriedly into the garden , L. CEDRIC , with more leisurely dignity , lights a cigarette and is about to follow her when he stops and turns .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: By the way , I do n't think we shall stay long .

sp.speaker: GASTON
sp.p: After looking at FLORA in the garden , impartially and cheerfully .It is strange how English people have shame of being married . One would say it was a crime in England . A young man and young lady in English hotel — they like better that one should think they not married . It is different in Switzerland . In Switzerland we are proud . We tell all the world . Why not ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: So you come from Switzerland ?

sp.speaker: GASTON
sp.p: Oh , yes . I am not Englisheagerly .Geneva . My father is a fabricant , a ——

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Manufacturer .

sp.speaker: GASTON
sp.p: Yes , manufacturer of door-mats . My father makes door-mats for all the hotels in Switzerland . Very big ! Very important ! He says — I must go into the hotel business . He will buy me a hotel . I learn everything . We do that in Switzerland . We are scientifique . I have been in the kitchens . Now I am waiter . No shame . Nobody could guess I am a gentleman .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: You must n't be too hard on yourself , my friend . And so you 've come to England ?

sp.speaker: GASTON
sp.p: My father says , Go to England . Study the English caractère in England . Very valuable . When I come to London I could not speak English — no !

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: When was that ? Last week ?

sp.speaker: GASTON
sp.p: No . It is a year , nearly . But I had at once a situation , the first day , at the Grand Babylon Hotel .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Rather awkward , was n't it , not knowing English ?

sp.speaker: GASTON
sp.p: Yes . That fatigues one — to hear a strange language all the day .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: I meant for the customers .

sp.speaker: GASTON
sp.p: Nonchalant gesture .They are now well habituated . Many of them learn French or German , it saves time . English people are so practical . They are not logique , but they are practical . Now to-day I speak German , Italian , as perfectly as English .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Remarkable ! But surely a man of your enormous ability is wasted in a sleepy place like this .... Perhaps you find it amusing , though .

sp.speaker: GASTON
sp.p: Shakes his head . Passionately .Dull ! It is for my health that I am here . Sleepy ! Ah , my God !Disdainfully .But all England sleeps .... But next month I go to Germany . I shall have done England .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: You like Germany .

sp.speaker: GASTON
sp.p: Ah ! What a country ! What organisation ! What science ! Never sleeps ! Always conquers !Patronisingly .Do you think in your business the Germans will not conquer , at the end ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: My business ?

sp.speaker: GASTON
sp.p: Yes . Aeroplanes .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: So you know that ?

sp.speaker: GASTON
sp.p: I know everything .... Look at anileen !

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Anileen ?

sp.speaker: GASTON
sp.p: Yes . Anileen — colours .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Ah ! You mean aniline dyes .

sp.speaker: GASTON
sp.p: Yes , I said so .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: What about them ?

sp.speaker: GASTON
sp.p: What about them ? England invented them . Germany has taken them from you — all . That is science . All German now . So with aeroplanes . England and France — proud , very proud . But at the end , you will see ... at the end .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: GASTON
sp.p: And soon .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: I say , if it is n't a rude question , how did you guess that we were — er — on our honeymoon ? It might be useful for me to know .

sp.speaker: GASTON
sp.p: Ah , now — again ! I read , I study . I alone in this sleepy place . By example , no afternoon newspapers — none — came into this place till I ordered one at the railway . I insisted . “ The Piccadilly Gazette ” — you know — Thackeray — “ written by gentlemen for gentlemen . ” I read it every day . Ah ! And is it not afraid of Germany !

lg.l: Do you mean there 's something about my marriage in the
“ Piccadilly Gazette ” ?

sp.speaker: GASTON
sp.p: Yes . Do you want to read it ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Well , I should rather like to see it , if I 'm not interfering with your studies .

sp.speaker: GASTON
sp.p: Taking paper out of his pocket .There !Stands waiting in a suggestive attitude .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Accepting paper .Thanks !Looks at him and gives him a tip .

lg.l: Thanks !... And you will see about
Klopstock too .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: What about Klopstock ?

sp.speaker: GASTON
sp.p: He comes to England soon as he has flyed at Breslau . Ah ! You will see !Exit R. with tray .

div.stage: CEDRIC sits down with paper , and begins to read .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Quietly .Oh !

div.stage: He drops the end of his cigarette into a flower-pot ; then takes a cigar from his case , cuts it , puts it in his mouth , and produces a matchbox , but does not light it .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Oh , indeed !

div.stage: He goes to the window , and taps on one of the closed panes . After a moment FLORA appears at the open part of the window . CEDRIC , with a motion of the hand , indicates that he wishes her to enter .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Off , in a conspiratorial whisper .Has the reader of hearts quite gone ?CEDRIC nods .Come out .CEDRIC beckons her inwards with his finger .

div.stage: Enter FLORA , L .

lg.l: Oh , Cedric ! What a blow ! We 're the honeymoon couple now of
Pixton-on-Sea . How did he guess ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Scarcely listening to her .Fluff , read thishands her paper with his finger on a particular paragraphTop of second column .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Reads .“ We are informed that Mr. Cedric Haslam , the celebrated aviatorCEDRIC shows surprisewas married privately this morning at Chelmsford to Mrs. Flora Lloyd , widow of the late Mr. Artemus Lloyd , stockbroker , who at one time was a well-known figure in the Kaffir Circus . Mr. and Mrs. Reach Haslam , the bridegroom 's parents , and his brother , Mr. Charles Haslam , were present . The happy pair are spending the first part of the honeymoon at Pixton-on-Sea . By a curious coincidence , Mrs. Reach Haslam 's new novel , ‘ The Wiving of the Chancellor , ’ appears on the very day of the marriage of her eldest son . ”Shaking her head .Only one thing is possible . Flight . Immediate flight ! And plenty of it ! Cedric , I suppose this is your dear mother 's doing ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: I should doubt it . More probably some accidental leakage . She hates the very thought of self-advertisement .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Oh ! I know . But I 've always noticed she 's somewhat unlucky in the matter of leakages . Your father ought to study plumbing .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Slightly impatient .That 's nothing . That 's not what I wanted you to read . I had n't even noticed that . Look !Pointing to a paragraph .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: “ Dissensions in the Cabinet . Extraordinary rumours . ”

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: No , no .Takes the paper and reads .“ The German Invasion . To-morrow , upon the conclusion of the Breslau meeting , Herr Klopstock will pack up his victorious new mono-plane and start for England . He announces his intention of trying within three weeks for the ten thousand pounds prize recently offered by the Aero Club to the first aviator who flies over Snowdon . Herr Klopstock , who has already , we understand , taken the whole of a hotel at Beddgelert for the accommodation of his staff , is convinced that his machine will rise easily to at least four thousand feet . The Kaiser has just christened the aeroplane the Black Eagle , by telegraph , and has assured the renowned aviator and ex-professor of the heartiest good wishes of himself and his house . His youngest grandchild , Prince — um — um — Fatherland — um — The news will certainly create a considerable sensation in England as it has done in Germany . ” I should say it would .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Why should it ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: What ! The Kaiser 's Black Eagle flying over the highest mountain in England , and getting ten thousand pounds for the job ! It 's unthinkable ! How does it strike you ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: It strikes me that it would have been much simpler and less expensive not to have offered the ten thousand pounds . It 's altogether too tempting . Besides , it seems to me anybody ought to be able to fly over a little thing like Snowdon , seeing how they sail over the Pyrenees and all that sort of thing .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: My adorable child , do n't talk like a member of the public . Henceforth you are in the know . The fogs alone make Snowdon worse than the Pyrenees . And then the Aero Club has been clever enough to ordain that the aviator is to start and land within four miles of the summit . How is a man to get off on such ground , and where is he to land without breaking wood ? And then the business of finding his way ! He 's bound to do a lot of corkscrewing to get up , and nothing less than six thousand feet would be safe .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: With a gesture dismissing all that .Well , I do n't think it 's quite nice of Mr. Klopstock . It ought to have occurred to him . But then , it never does seem to occur to Germans .... I 've often noticed that in hotels . They do n't seem to perceive .Different tone .Will he succeed ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: He might . I do n't think he would ; not with his present horse-power ; but he just might .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Well , most probably he wo n't . And then you can try in July as you originally intended , and get the money after all . Then there will have been some sense in the prize , anyway .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: It is n't the money .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Surely it is n't the mountain ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Following his own thought .We 've got to come out on top in this business . I must get to business in the middle of next week . It 'll take a day to modify those wingtips , and another to tune her up . Oh ! I shall be ready long before he is . But I 'll give him a chance to get nicely installed in his hotel . I should like Herr Klopstock and his crew to admire the beautiful scenery .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Casually .You must be at the works next week ?

lg.l: It 's me or nobody ! No use trying to disguise that fact ,
Fluff !

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Perhaps in the heat of the moment you 've forgotten that you happened to get married this morning , Cedric .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: I wish we had n't happened to get married this morning .She looks at him .I mean , I wish we 'd happened to get married a week ago . Frantic nuisance ! However , there you are ! It simply means we shall be fixed up a bit sooner in the flat ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: But the flat wo n't be anything like ready by next week .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Never mind , we 'll sleep at the Grand Babylon , or in the backyard .A little pause .Of course as a nuisance it completely baffles description .... To-day of all days .... However , Fluff , as I said before with profound truth — there you are ! It would never do in this world to give the German lot even a chance . The thing 's too spectacular — altogether too spectacular . If it was a question of beating us quietly and for ever in technics or manufacture , the B. P . would n't think twice about it ; but Snowdon is Snowdon , and a black eagle is a black eagle , andcomicallyin short , madam , England will turn to your husband in its hour of peril . In other words , Fluff , it 's up to me .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Lightly .I say , Cedric .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I thought we were agreed about a full calendar month .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: After a pause ; as lightly as possible .Do you mean you think I ought to let Snowdon slide ? Do you really ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Yes , of course . Do n't you ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: You are n't serious ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Persuasively .My dearest boy , is there any reason why I should n't differ from you and yet be serious ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: No , of course not . But in a case like this — if there was anybody else to take my place , I would n't mind . Of course Smith-James could do it if only he would use our machine — but he wo n't . Nothing would induce him to . So as I keep on saying — there you are !

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: But what does it matter ? Is it because the other man 's machine has been called the Black Eagle in a telegram that you ——

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Yes , partly .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Oh ! So that if this canvas-backed duck flies first over a lump of mud called Snowdon ——

lg.l: But do n't I tell you Snowdon is the highest mountain in
England ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: No , it is n't .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Pardon me . Three thousand five hundred and seventy feet . The next highest is ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Well , you go and tell Lloyd George that Snowdon is the highest mountain in England , and see what you 'll get .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Wales , then . It 's all the same .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: With great charm .If you 're thinking of the ten thousand pounds , I do n't mind informing you , as a great secret , that I would n't sell a single day of my honeymoon with you for ten times ten thousand pounds . But I told you I wanted an expensive honeymoon , did n't I ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Shaking his head and with calm certainty .The money does n't influence me that much !Snaps his fingers .I do n't wish to flatter myself , but I think I could light your cigarette with a bank note as gracefully as anybody . No ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: You 're pulling away at that cigar of yours , but I suppose you know it is n't lighted .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Is n't it ?As he lights the cigar .No ! This Snowdon business . Well , it 's a symbolhalf to himselfI wonder how I can make you understand that .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Fascinatingly .Oh ! Force is unnecessary , I understand that . But who was it said just now that the honeymoon was a symbol ? It stands for all our married life . It 's the most exciting and interesting time we shall ever have . And you can n't put a honeymoon off , you know . It is n't like a box of cigars that you can keep in a cupboard and enjoy one of them every now and then when you 've got a few minutes to spare . It must happen now or never . You can n't postpone it . You can only kill it .Smiles lightly .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Taking hold of her , in a caressing tone .She 's tragic !

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Disengaging herself .Oh , no !

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Now just listen to me , Fluff . I 'm really thinking at least as much of you as of myself . This affair is bound to have an influence on my career .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: And what about its influence on mine ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Same thing . I suppose our interests are identical .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: My poor simple boy , do you really believe that ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Well , dash it , are n't you my wife ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: So far as I 'm concerned , it would be more correct to say that you 're my husband . In fact , you 've got a career as my husband .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Anxious to be fair .Certainly . And you as my wife . But ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: One second , dearest . You 're unique as an aviator , are n't you ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Conventionally modest .Oh — well ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Now . Man to man . Give your modesty a rest . Really , do n't you consider you 've proved yourself unique in your line ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Hesitatingly , chivalrously .I suppose I 'm just about as unique in my line as you are in yours , my dear .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Now that 's very nice of you .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Not at all .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Yes , it is , because it 's exactly what I wanted you to say . You 've often said that I 'm unique , and I just wanted you to say it again at this identical particular instant . Of course I could have reminded you of it , but that would n't have been quite so effective . That 's why it 's very nice of you .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: So you are unique — I 'll say it as often as you like .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I warn you , you 're giving yourself away .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Delighted !

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I would n't care to repeat all the lovely adjectives you 've used about me . If you were n't such a determined enemy of gush and superlatives — people might suspect that sometimes you exaggerated the tiniest bit when you talked about me , to me . But of course I know you never do exaggerate , at any rate consciously , and you know you 're a very good judge .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: What of ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Us !... Now look here , Cedric , do n't you think it would be a pity to stop this creature , who is so unique in her line , from giving a full exhibition of her unique powers at a unique moment ; at the very height of her career . You know , she 'll never have another opportunity like this of proving that she really is unique in her line .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: What do you call her line ? Let 's be clear .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Quietly , off-handedly , after a pause .To charm . Merely that .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: By God ! She can do that . Butwinningly , but half to himself, I hardly know how to put it .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I think you do , dearest ; but you 're so nice , you do n't like to . You wanted to make a comparison between the importance of your line and the importance of mine . I admit all that . I 'm quite humble . I fully admit that if Hyde Park were full of aviators and Battersea Park were full of charming young women , rather pretty and — er — chic —gesture to show off her frock— I fully admit that not a man among you would ever dream — of crossing the river . I fully admit that if every aviator in Europe gave up business to-morrow the entire world would go into mourning , whereas if all the charming women retired from business they 'd never be missed . Still ——

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Appreciative .You 're a witty girl ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: We 're both rather witty , are n't we , at times ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: But the fact is I was n't going to make any comparison at all between our respective lines . I was only going to point out that you can keep on being charming all the time . You 're always charming ; you 're always doing your line . Whereas for my line I have to choose times and seasons — or rather I do n't choose ‘ em , they 're chosen for me , as , for instance , just now . Wherever we are , honeymoon or no honeymoon , you 're — well , you 're giving an exhibition flight .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Now , Cedric , your good nature 's getting the better of your sincerity . I 'm not always charming . Ask your dear mother . And have you forgotten our historic shindy about the length of your moustache scarcely three months ago ? I 'm not always charming . And I do n't want to be always charming . Who would ? As for exhibition flights , you 've never seen me give one . You think you have , but what you 've seen up to now is nothing . I do n't mind telling you that I had arranged a rather sensational exhibition flight for the next month . It would last just thirty-one days . I do n't mind telling you that I 've thought a good deal about it , and made all my elaborate preparations . It really would be a pity to interfere with it . And you know it can n't be postponed . I do n't choose time and season any more than you do .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: But surely , Fluff , this flight can proceed , as I say , wherever we are ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: You think so ? And what about my grandstand ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: I shall always be your grandstand .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Shall you ? I can only do my best when I 've got the undivided attention of my audience . I hope I should never come quite to earth , but I do n't see myself being unique in my line for the benefit of a man who is busywith the faintest touch of irony in her tonecounting the misfires in his motor , or dreaming about the barometer .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Naturally , if you do n't see the importance of this Snowdon business to us ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Consciously very charming again .But I do see it perfectly well . A woman unique in her own line is not necessarily a gaping idiot in every other line . I admit the immense importance of Snowdon to us . I wo n't argue . In my time I 've been told that I was too well-dressed to be able to argue . I simply want to ask you this — what , for you , is the most important thing in life ? Now , let 's be straight . Have you married as a supreme end , or is your supreme end to move yourself about in the air without visible means of support ? Nowsmiling, look me in the face , and be a man .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: You 're putting very fundamental questions .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Is marriage a relaxation from flying , or do you fly in order to have the means for practising the whole art of marriage under favourable conditions ? Do you live most intensely when you 're battling with the breeze , or when you 'redropping her voicewith me ? I only want to know . Because if you live most intensely when you 're with me , this honeymoon should be worth more to us than forty Snowdons .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: A little coldly .Say no more , Snowdon is chucked . Of course , my position is impossible . You have only to insist .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Losing her self-control .Insist ? Insist that you neglect an aeroplane so that you can stay with me ? My dear boy , I 'm incapable of taking such a mean advantage of an aeroplane . An aeroplane can n't insist . And I can assure you I sha n't .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Do you know that you 're scarcely logical ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Not logical ? In not insisting ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Somewhat at a loss .I mean generally . For instance , when we began , your first argument was that we could n't shorten the honeymoon because the flat would n't be ready .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: One can n't think of everything at once . You must n't forget I 've never been called to the bar . If I 'd known what was coming , no doubt I should have prepared my case and had it typewritten , and sent copies to the press .... And then what about your being illogical ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Me ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Yes . When I ask you for a straight answer you protest that I 'm putting very fundamental questions . Did you expect me to put shallow questions ? Did you expect me to enquire whether you 'd used Pears ’ soap ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Now look here , Fluffiest ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Angry .Cedric , I wish you would n't call me that . You 've only started it since we were married . I can stand Fluff , but I do n't like Fluffy , and my objection to Fluffiest is intense .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: I beg your pardon .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Recovering herself sweetly .It 's I who beg yours . For the moment I was forgetting that “ common superficial politeness ” that you ranked with common-sense .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: My dear child , everything 's all right . The honeymoon shall not be shortened by a single day . Everything 's absolutely all right .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Shakes her head .It is n't . You 're only giving way to please me .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Well , really ——laughing

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Cedric . Honestly . Yes or no . Do you think I ought to yield to the aeroplane ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: They look at each other .I think you ought n't to ask quite such questions ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Agreeing .No . Such questions ought to be asked earlier . But human nature is so — human , that probably it would n't be any use asking them any earlier . They might even be considered rude . In fact , it is considered rude for fiancés to worry each other with any questions that really matter .Pause . In a vague voice .Whether you prefer a flat or a house , and the colour of the drawing-room chairs — that 's about as far as you are supposed to go .Another pause .Well ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Approaching her .What ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Do you think I ought to yield to the aeroplane ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Stands still , very firmly .My dear girl , if you ask me to be straight , I think the Snowdon business is n't a thing to be neglected .Pause at high tension .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Plaintively .Common-sense does n't seem to be such a wonderful cure for difficulties after all .Fiercely .Oh ! If I had faith , would n't I just move that mountain into the sea !Gives a sob .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Flora , what can I say ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Controlling herself .There 's nothing else to be said — by either of us . It 's — it 's hopeless .

div.stage: Enter CHARLES HASLAM , R ., cautiously . He is in motoring attire .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: At the door , to someone outside .It 's all right . We 've caught ‘ emwithin the room

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Extremely puzzled ; frowning .Hello !

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Hello !... Flora , what 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Collecting herself ; ironically .Oh , nothing ! nothing ! This is a nice kind idea of yours , to come and relieve our solitude , but did you expect us not to be startled ?

div.stage: Enter MR. REACH HASLAM .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Hello .MR. REACH HASLAM gives a deprecating gesture .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: My dear Flora !

div.stage: Enter MRS. REACH HASLAM .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Any more ?

div.stage: Enter GASTON .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Well , this is a pleasure . Unusual perhaps ——

sp.speaker: MRS. REACH HASLAM
sp.p: My dear son , my dear Flora ——Turns to Mr. Reach Haslam .Father ——Stops .

sp.speaker: MR. REACH HASLAM
sp.p: To GASTON , who is hovering inquisitively about .If there is the slightest doubt in your mind as to the exact geographical situation of the door ——

sp.speaker: GASTON
sp.p: Please ?Meaning “ I beg your pardon , I did n't catch what you said ! ”

div.stage: MR. REACH HASLAM goes to door , R ., and signals to GASTON to depart . Exit GASTON . MR. REACH HASLAM closes door .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Aside to CHARLES .What the hell 's up ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Loudly .Well , Rick ——

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Charles , what did I tell you before you came in ? I 'll thank you to go and sit down over there .CHARLES obeys .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Suppose we all sit down , shall we ? Well , what did you tell him before he came in ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Sits .Believe me , Flora , I never felt so unequal to a situation in my life .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Look here , dad , do you mind telling me in one word what this is all about ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Yes , your father will tell you . The circumstances are exceedingly difficult — in fact , painful . But they have to be faced , and faced with dignity . The various necessary steps must be taken , in their proper order , very carefully . The first step is to inform you and Flora of the facts . Your father will inform you ; as the head of the family , and the fount of authority , the statement comes more properly from him . I decided that absolutely as we motored down .To MR. REACH HASLAM .Dear ——

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Yes , dear .To CEDRIC and FLORA .You know we went straight back to town when you 'd left the church . As soon as we had ——

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Interrupting , to CEDRIC and FLORA .You need n't be alarmed . As I said , the circumstances are painful , but once faced as we shall face them , they really amount to nothing . The principal thing was to catch you in time . Thank heaven , we 've done that !

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Thank my masterly and audacious driving !

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Staring him down .If we had failed !Gesture of despair to MR. REACH HASLAM .Dear ——

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Nodding to her politely .As soon as we had finished lunch your mother set herself to work , her work being very much behind ——

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Never mind all that . Do it as gently as you can , but come to the point at once . I am quite sure that is best .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: The telephone ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: The telephone .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Nodding to her politely .We were rung up on the telephone . Your mother was walking about in meditation , and as she was nearest to the telephone she answered it . She then said to me , “ It 's the Bishop of Chelmsford . ” I was at the desk . In another moment she asked me to come to the telephone and listen for myself as she could scarcely believe her ears . I did so , and the Bishop — he was telephoning from the Palace at Chelmsford — repeated at my request what he had said to your mother , namely , that that curate who — er — officiated this morning , suddenly awakened to a sense of beauty ——

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Sense of duty .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: I quite understood “ beauty . ” It 's true the Bishop has n't got a good telephone voice — probably more impressive at a confirmation than on the telephone . I heard “ beauty . ” However ——

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Sense of duty .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: No doubt you are right . I seemed to gather that it was Flora 's beauty that had roused his conscience .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Oh , no !

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: That had what ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Coming towards the group , unable to control his impatience .Oh , hang it ! The curate was a sham curate — not a curate at all .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Taking it in .A sham curate !

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: But surely such things do n't happen ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: That 's what many people said when I made a shopwalker successfully personate an archdeacon in “ The Woman of Kent . ” Everyone said so until Mr. Gladstone wrote that he found the episode quite convincing . You remember , dear ?

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Vividly .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: I assure you it happens quite frequently that from one cause or another people who think they are married are not married . Why , sometimes special Acts of Parliament have to be passed in order to set things right — when they 've gone altogether too far . I well recall that when I studied this subject , as of course I did , coming across a case in which , owing to a church having been consecrated very carelessly , a lady who supposed herself to be the legitimate mother of sixteen children — poor thing ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Interrupting .But do you mean to say we are n't married ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Well , of course , I want to put it as gently as possible , but the fact is ——looking at her husband

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: It would be an exaggeration to say that you are married .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: If my idea had been accepted of having the Bishop to officiate — and he would have been only too enchanted — in the cathedral , this dreadful thing could not have occurred . No case of personating a bishop has ever been known .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: But what are we to do ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Airily .Well , you must make the best of it .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Outraged .Certainly not , Charles , you are astounding . It would have looked better of you if you had remained outside in charge of the car . Make the best of it , indeed !To MR. REACH HASLAM .Father ——

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: To CEDRIC .For the moment a policy of masterly inactivity seems to be indicated .CURTAIN .NOTES ON CHARACTERS IN ACT II

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP OF CHELMSFORD
sp.p: Celibate . The typical Bishop who , while the bent of his mind is reactionary , convinces himself that he is exceedingly modern , and moving with the rapid times . No real intellectual quality , but energetic and self-adaptive .

sp.speaker: MR. FRAMPINGTON
sp.p: A bland young man , with perfect manners and perfect sangfroid . A single-minded person of immense intellectual and spiritual originality . To himself he does not seem at all peculiar , but merely natural .

sp.speaker: CUTHBERT
sp.p: Just a plain modern butler . I particularly do not want this trifling part to be embroidered by the conventional butler “ business . ” If any genuine realistic butler “ business ” can be brought into it , well and good .

div.head: ACT II .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: REACH HASLAM 'S study . A large apartment , richly and suitably furnished . The retreat of one of the most successful , most wealthy , and most majestic novelists in the world . Large and splendid deskfor two people , sitting opposite each otherabout the middle of the room . Door back leading to hall , etc . Door , L ., leading to drawing-room . Down stage , left , a sofa , which is partly hidden by a screen from the view of anyone entering by door , L. Date calendar on desk . Telephone . All the HASLAMS except CHARLES are in evening dress . FLORA is elaborately attired , with a light Egyptian shawl on her shoulders , and a fan .

div.stage: TIME : Same evening . Immediately after dinner . The BISHOP is waiting , alone . Enter to him , from door back , MRS. REACH HASLAM followed by MR. REACH HASLAM .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: As she enters .Ah ! Bishop . How good of you !Shakes hands .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Shaking hands with Mr. Reach Haslam .My dear Mrs. Reach Haslam . Not at all ! I blush for my diocese — that such a deplorable and distressing accident should have occurred in it .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Then it really is true ?

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: But I told you on the telephone .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: I know , I know ! I was only hoping against hope that perhaps after all you might have found that the marriage was legal .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Shaking his head .No . His late father was undoubtedly in orders , his late brother also . But he himself was no more ordained than you are .To MR. REACH HASLAM , who recoils .He presumed on his relationships .... In fact , his sole qualification seems to have been two old suits of his brother 's .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Well , after all , it is perhaps better so .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Better , dear lady ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: I mean that you have not brought good news at the eleventh hour . Really ——Looking at MR. REACH HASLAM .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: To whom the BISHOP , puzzled , turns for an explanation .My wife , with her novelist 's instinct , perceives the situation that would be created if we had to go into the drawing-room now and say to them suddenly , “ Well , you are married , after all . ”

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Excessively delicate . They would naturally have to leave the house at once .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Quite so . I cannot tell you how relieved I was to get your wire saying that you had overtaken them in time . Young people make such a mystery of the honeymoon nowadays that often they do n't even leave a postal address . A dangerous innovation !

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Evidently .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: I gather that you have brought them both here , poor things !

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: It seemed the wisest course . I consulted my husband , and he quite agreed with me that in view of the unusual circumstances we ought to act with the greatest prudence — for their sakes ! And so we motored quietly back to town and got here just in time for dinner . My son drove . I sat by his side . There was n't room for their heavy luggage , and so Charlie is bringing that up by train . Charles is my other son ....Sighs .And here we are !

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Admirable ! It 's a case of ——

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: As you were .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Just so ! Really a terrible blow to them — must have been ! And to you , and to you ! An appalling shock ! How have they borne it ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Well —turning to MR. R. HASLAMFather , how should you say they have borne it ?

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Grimly . That is — on the grim side .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Ah !

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Of course , my Lord , we are taking it for granted that the matter can be put right to-morrow , without fail , and beyond question . I have tried to comfort them with that absolute assurance .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: My dear lady . Without fail ! At any hour ! any hour ... up to three o'clock . That is why I have come specially to town — to convince you by my presence of my horror at the — er — crime , my sympathy with its innocent victims , and my utter determination that the ceremony shall be performed again to-morrow morning under my personal supervision and guarantee . I feel that I cannot do too much .

div.stage: During the last words enter CUTHBERT , back , with salver of letters and press cuttings , followed by parlour-maid with a tray of newspaper packets .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Will you excuse my husband while he deals with the post ?

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: I beg ——MR. REACH HASLAM sits down to desk and takes the post . Exeunt SERVANTS .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: I ought to apologise for receiving you in my study , but I thought — my husband thought — we had better see you first alone . Are those the press cuttings , father ?

div.stage: MR. REACH HASLAM , nodding , opens press cuttings .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: But for this unfortunate contretemps , what a charming coincidence that your new book should be published to-day of all days !

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: So you find time in your busy life , Bishop , to keep abreast of modern literature — even novels ?

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Even novels ! My dear lady , there is no greater force for good .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Or for evil — alas !

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Quite so ! I have often thought — I have indeed said so from the platform — that the two most truly important influences for good in our generation are your novels and the leaflets of the National Society for Promoting the Education of the Poor in the Principles of the Established Church .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Indeed ! Father , do you recall that press-cutting ?

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Busy .No .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: It was reported in our Diocesan Magazine .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: And yet , my dear Bishop , I have more than once felt it my duty to criticise the Church rather sharply in my work .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: I know , I know . We bow the head , we kiss the rod .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: In my new novel I am back in politics again . Have you seen it yet ?

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: No , not yet . But I have already ordered it from Boot 's .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Boot 's ?

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Yes , the cash chemists . I find their circulating library the most economical of all . And I have to be particular . As you know , I publish every year a detailed account of all my expenditure , personal and otherwise , and too large a sum for books might be misconstrued as self-indulgence , especially in a bachelor .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Ah , yes .Handing him a book .Here is a copy .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Pretty cover .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: To his wife , in a low tone .Twenty-one columns .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Pleased .Really !

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Looking up .Twenty-one columns ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: We are treating you without ceremony , my dear Bishop . My husband has just calculated the total length of the reviews of my book that have appeared in the London papers on the first day . Of course we attach no value whatever to the actual opinions expressed — the critics have to work in such a hurry — and they are so sadly unfitted for their work , poor dears — but the amount of space given is an excellent indication of the public importance ascribed to the book .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Who has been inspecting the book .How true !

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: To Mr. REACH HASLAM .Anything special ?

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: No . “ Surpassed herself , ” seven or eight times . “ Masterpiece , ” fourteen times . The “ Piccadilly Gazette ” is unfavourable .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Very ?

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Better tell me .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Deprecating gesture , reads .“ The book is of course admirable in workmanship , knowledge and insight , but Mrs. Reach Haslam has not , if the truth must be told , surpassed herself . ”

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: If I 'd known about that when I saw their lady reporter this morning !...

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Putting the book down .Enthralling narrative ! Enthralling ! Now , my dear ladyrising

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Interrupting him .Please sit down . As you are having a glimpse of me in my profession to-night , I want to ask you one or two professional questions — about the psychology of that false curate .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Sitting down again .Yes , yes . Psychology . Just so .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: I never lose an opportunity of gathering material . Father , will you mind taking down ? My husband is good enough to act as my stenographer .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Touching !

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Now I noticed nothing remarkable about that curate .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Agreeing .No . And yet , you know — curious thing — he 's a gentleman , quite ! Oh , quite ! And I even remember once meeting his father , when I was Court Chaplain , at a garden party in aid of the Additional Curates Society .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Repeating what he has written .Curates Society .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: But why should he choose to personate a curate ? That is what is so interesting to a novelist . Why a curate ? It could n't have been for the money , or the glory .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Glory .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: The case is highly peculiar . He is certainly not without means , or brains . My opinion is that his action was due to excessive intellectual curiosity . He told me he wanted to feel what it was like to be a curate .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Yet he looked quite sane .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Oh , quite ! Astonishing story ! His brother , through the influence of the Primate , had been engaged as curate , by the Vicar of St. Saviour 's , Chelmsford , subject to an interview . This brother had been doing some chaplaining in Switzerland — just rough winter work . On the way home he died suddenly in Paris . Well , our friend of this morning calmly took up the dead man 's identity . Came to Chelmsford , conquered the simple Vicar , and was at once accepted . That was two months ago .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Ago .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: But how dangerous .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: So I pointed out to him . His reply was that it was just the danger that had attracted him — coupled with the desire to understand why the members of his family had had such a passion for curacy . It seems that two of his sisters have espoused curates . This will be a grievous blow for all of them .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: All of them .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: But why should the man be struck with remorse just now ?

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Well , his explanation is that he was so moved by the bride 's beauty .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Duty .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Beauty .Gesture of mild triumph from MR. REACH HASLAM to MRS. REACH HASLAM .He could not bear to think that any action of his should cause — er — inconvenience to a woman so beautiful . Hence he came to me at once . Fortunately I happened to be at the Palace .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Had he performed any other marriages ?

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Happily none ; but he had celebrated ten funerals and four baptisms . However these did not seem to trouble him in the least , I regret to say . It was the wedding alone that roused his conscience .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Conscience .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Of course you sent for the police .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: I trust and believe that he is now in prison . But I did not send for the police . The Church has its dignity to maintain against the civil judicature in these modern days . Also with so much irreligion — shall I say ?— flaunting in the very air , She must avoid scandal — particularly local scandal . London scandal is less deleterious . Accordingly I brought the young man up to town with me , and I put him into a cab for the police-station , where he will surrender himself of his own free will to the law . I prefer that way . It is , perhaps , original ; but nowadays we Bishops have to be original .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: But do you really suppose he has surrendered ?

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: I am sure of it . I cannot pretend to your skill in reading character , dear lady , but I know a gentleman at sight .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Sight .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Of course , if one put such a story into a novel , it would never be believed . That 's the worst of real life .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: And yet this distressing affair reminded me strongly of the false archdeacon in “ The Woman of Kent . ”

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Pleased .Ah ! You remember my early book ?

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Protestingly .My dear lady ! You have no more earnest student ! And may I add that from the first I found that episode of the false archdeacon entirely convincing . Its convincingness was one of the very few points on which I shared the opinions of the late Mr. Gladstone . “ The Woman of Kent ” has always been a favourite of mine among your novels . It must have had a vast circulation .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: How many copies , father ?

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Without looking up from the desk .One hundred and seventy-two thousand .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Wonderful memory !

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Is it not ? He knows more about my books than I do myself , far more .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Touching .Rising .I must go — reluctantly . Now what time shall we say for to-morrow morning ? I am absolutely at your disposal .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: But do we understand that you mean to conduct the ceremony in person ?

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: I do . I wish particularly to show by my presence at the altar my sense of what complete reparation is due to you — due to you all .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: I think we had better consult Flora herself .Rings bell .As you know , my original intention was that you should be asked to preside at the ceremony . But the young people insisted on a simple curate — doubtless from modesty , my dear Bishop .... Would that I had been firm in the first instance !

div.stage: Enter CUTHBERT , back .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Is Mrs. Lloyd in the drawing-room ?

sp.speaker: CUTHBERT
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: With Mr. Cedric ?

sp.speaker: CUTHBERT
sp.p: No , ma'am . She is alone .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Will you tell her that I should be very much obliged if she could join us here for a moment .

sp.speaker: CUTHBERT
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .... A representative of the “ Piccadilly Gazette ” has just called , ma'am — for information . A male representative .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: “ The Piccadilly ” !To MR. R. HASLAM .The audacity !To CUTHBERT .About what ?CUTHBERT makes a gesture of embarrassment .You told him to call again to-morrow ?

sp.speaker: CUTHBERT
sp.p: No , ma'am . He 's waiting .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Father , would you mind going out to him ?Exit CUTHBERT .I really wonder at Cuthbert !To BISHOP .We have an absolute rule against seeing journalists after dinner . As you know , Bishop , I detest notoriety . Hence our rule . And yet Cuthbert allows this man to wait !

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Going to door .Cuthbert is not himself . Cuthbert has been staggered by the events of the day . The strain of pretending that nothing in the least unusual has happened must be tremendous . Allowance should be made for Cuthbert . How shall I treat this invader ?

div.stage: The BISHOP dips into the novel .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Well , without actually mentioning their review , perhaps you might just indicate by your manner ——

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: These journalists are so obtuse , but still ——

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: I think perhaps if you said that we cannot understand how a purely private matter can interest the public , but that if they must know , the Bishop is here in person , and ——MR. REACH HASLAM nods .You think that will be judicious ?

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Quite .Exit back .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Putting down the book .Enthralling !

div.stage: Enter FLORA , L .

lg.l: Flora , darling , this is the Bishop of
Chelmsford — Mrs. Lloyd , my — er — prospective daughter-in-law .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Stiffly .My lord .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: My dear young lady , I have already tried to express to Mrs. Haslam my consternation , my shame , at the ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Smiling coldly .I am sure that is sufficient .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: The Bishop has come to town specially to see us , Flora . In order to guard against any possibility of further accident , he has kindly suggested that he should officiate himself to-morrow morning .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: To BISHOP .It 's really very good of you .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Relieved .Is it not ?

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: At what hour ? I am entirely at your disposal .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Oh , any time !

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Noon ? If you come down by the nine-fifteen train ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: That will do perfectly .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Where is Cedric , dear ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I have no idea . Shall I see ?Exit , L .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: The dear child has evidently been much upset .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: We all have .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Ravishing creature ! Who was Mr. Lloyd ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: He seems to have been on the Stock Exchange . He was a Chelmsford man , and had a house just outside the town .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Indeed ! I never met him . Did he leave a large fortune ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Oh , no ! The house — not much else , I believe .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Probably an admiration for your work was the original basis of the — er ——

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Oh , no ! I was first introduced to Mrs. Lloyd by Charlie , my second son . In fact , quite confidentially , Bishop ; we thought it was a match between them .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: But heaven decided otherwise ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Cedric decided otherwise .

div.stage: Enter MR. R. HASLAM , back .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Flora tells me that it is arranged for to-morrow .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Yes . I have just been hearing from Mrs. Haslam how this beautiful young lady has attracted both your sons .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Very catching . Ran through the family .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Ha , ha !Seriously .Ravishing creature !

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Has Charlie come yet ?

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: If he is n't here soon I fear he 'll be late for the office . And he 's had no sleep to-day , poor boy .To BISHOP .Charles is the assistant manager of the circulation department of the “ Daily Sentinel , ” and his hours are from 9. 30 at night till three in the morning .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: How trying ! I 'm afraid we little think when we open our newspaper at breakfast — I always read the “ Sentinel ” — we little think what an immense amount of endeavour ——

div.stage: Enter CHARLES , back .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Hullo ! Mater . No trace of any dinner for me in the dining-room . Here you stick me up with the luggage and all the dirty work ——

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Charles , the Bishop of Chelmsford .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: We have met once before , I think .Shaking hands .Now , dear Mrs. Haslamlooking at his watch, I have half an hour to get to Liverpool Street .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: You return to Chelmsford to-night ?

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Essential ! I have a midnight procession of drunkards . You know they call me “ the drunkards ’ Bishop . ” I am proud of the title .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Shaking hands .Exceedingly good of you to have come .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Not at all . The obligation is mine for your forbearance . Now — may I presume on our slight acquaintanceship ? If at any time you should think of adding a Bishop to your wonderful gallery of contemporary portraits , and I could be of assistance — need I say more ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: I have already drawn two .

sp.speaker: BISHOP
sp.p: Really ?

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Suffragans , my dear .

lg.l: Ah ! Suffragans ! I thought I could not have forgotten two
Bishops . Till to-morrow then , at noon . Young man , till to-morrow .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: As BISHOP and MR. R. HASLAM go out .Father , would you mind speaking firmly to Cuthbert about Charlie 's dinner ?

div.stage: Exeunt BISHOP and MR. REACH HASLAM , back .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Why the Bishop ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: He came up specially to arrange for to-morrow . Certainly it was the least he could do .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: To-morrow ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: The wedding .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Oh yes , of course , I was forgetting .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Really , Charlie , you get more and more absent-minded as you grow older . I 'm not sorry Cedric wo n't let you meddle with aeroplanes . The wedding will be at noon to-morrow . We go down by the nine-fifteen .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: With all that luggage again ! It would have been simpler to leave it where it was . Seven trunks ! What with cabs , tips , fares , excess , and a special omnibus , somebody owes me one pound thirteen , not to speak of compensation for the total loss of tea , dinner , and temper .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Well , you are always enthusiastic about Flora 's clothes . We acted for the best . We could n't tell exactly what would happen . Fortunately the Bishop saw at once that it was his duty to take things in hand himself .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: I should say that what the Bishop saw was a chance of getting himself into one of your books , mater .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: That also is possible .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Imitating the BISHOP .“ Need I say more ? ” What a cuckoo !

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Charles !

div.stage: Enter CEDRIC , L .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Has that dashed Bishop actually departed ? I began to think he was going to spend the night here .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Cedric ! I am ready to make great allowances , but I really do not know what has come over my sons .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Sorry , mother .To CHARLES .Hello ! You back ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Flora 's told you it 's all arranged for noon to-morrow ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: No . Have n't seen her .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Well , it is . And now , my boys , you can n't stay any longer in your mother 's study . My article for “ Harper 's ” must absolutely be finished to-night . Your father and I had been expecting a placid afternoon and evening of work .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: By the way , Rick . About that Klopstock business . Of course you 've seen the papers .CEDRIC nods .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Oh , yes . I quite intended to mention that , Cedric ; but really one has had so many things to think about — and my article , too ! How very awkward it is , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: I met one of our johnnies at Liverpool Street , and he was a little excited about it . And I may inform you it is n't often our johnnies do get excited .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Oh !Sits down on sofa .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: He told me they 'd received a later wire at the office , from Breslau , saying that Klopstock has had a private trial over a mountain near there — I forget the name — and done it , my boy ! Done it on his head !

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Has he , indeed ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: And he 'll be over here in a week or ten days , it seems . They want to know at the office exactly what you 're going to do . So I told the johnnie I should be seeing you to-night , and I 'd bring an official message . I had to explain to him a bit what had happened — could n't help it . I suppose you 'll be forced to cut the honeymoon next week and begin to get things into shape at once .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: It is annoying for you , dear , and for Flora , too !

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: I sha n't do any such thing .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: You surely wo n't let him ——

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: I sha n't do anything for a full month .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Do you mean to say you 'll let Klopstock get in first .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: If Klopstock chooses to try during my honeymoon , I can n't help that , can I ? Let somebody else have a shot . I 'm not the only aviator in England , confound it !

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Cedric !

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: You 're the only aviator in England that can get in front of Klopstock over Snowdon .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: I can n't help that .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: But , Cedric — surely your duty ——

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Oh ! d ——stopping himself

div.stage: Enter FLORA . As soon as she perceives CEDRIC , who has been hidden from her by the screen , she makes as if to leave the room again .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Recalling her .Flora .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: With false simplicity .So you are back , Charlie . What an angel you 've been to worry yourself with all that big luggage .

sp.speaker: CHARLIE
sp.p: Oh ! That 's all rightsurveying herI see you had at least one frock in the portmanteau . We were just discussing the Snowdon flight . So you two have decided ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: No , we really settled nothing . Cedric alone settles that , of course . All questions relating to aeroplanes should be addressed to the head of the flying department and not to the firm .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Rising , with restrained savageness .I tell you I shall do nothing whatever for a full month .Exit , L .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Trying to break the extreme awkwardness caused by CEDRIC 'S behaviour , in a bantering but affectionate tone .I suspect the fact is that the bones of a husband are doubly precious in her sight .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: But you do n't really think there is any special danger , do you , Flora dear ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Of course not . If I was n't convinced that Cedric in his aeroplane is a great deal safer than Charlie in a motor-car , or Paderewski at the end of a concert , or a cabinet minister at a public meeting , should I have gone as far as marrying him ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Then , seeing how serious it is for the country , why ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: My dear , you must ask Cedric . I do n't interfere with business .

div.stage: Enter CUTHBERT , back .

sp.speaker: CUTHBERT
sp.p: A Mr. Frampington , to see the Bishop , ma'am . I told him his Grace had gone , and now he asks to see either you or Mr. Haslam .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Mr. Frampington ? Where is your master ?

sp.speaker: CUTHBERT
sp.p: I believe he 's in the kitchen at the moment , ma'am .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Frampington ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Was n't that the name of our young hopeful this morning ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Brightening again .The imitation curate ? Of course it was !

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: But surely ——

sp.speaker: CUTHBERT
sp.p: He bears no resemblance to a curate , ma'am .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Then it is he ! Oh ! if it is , do let 's see him ! In private life he must be extremely interesting .To CUTHBERT .Show him in , will you , please ?

div.stage: Exit CUTHBERT .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Flora — really I do n't know what 's come over you all !

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: It seems to me that the curate has come over us all .

div.stage: Enter CUTHBERT , and FRAMPINGTON in tourist attire .
Exit CUTHBERT .

sp.speaker: FRAMPINGTON
sp.p: In a quite natural , easy tone .We meet again . I 'm so sorry to disturb you , Mrs. Haslam , but I 'm in a slight difficulty , and I hoped to find the Bishop here .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: The Bishop left a few minutes ago .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Wo n't you sit down ?Outraged glance from MRS. R. HASLAM . FRAMPINGTON sits down calmly .May one inquire what this slight difficulty is ?

sp.speaker: FRAMPINGTON
sp.p: After a little hesitation .I suppose the Bishop has explained everything ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: So far as everything is capable of explanation , yes .

sp.speaker: FRAMPINGTON
sp.p: I 'm glad of that . It makes the situation so much easier . No doubt the Bishop gave you all the messages of apology and regret that I asked him to deliver on my behalf .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: To MRS. REACH HASLAM .Did he ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: No . He only spoke for himself .

sp.speaker: FRAMPINGTON
sp.p: That was not nice of him .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: He told us you were a gentleman ——

sp.speaker: FRAMPINGTON
sp.p: Generous !

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: And that you had promised to go to the police-station and give yourself up of your own accord .

sp.speaker: FRAMPINGTON
sp.p: Quite correct . And as soon as I 'd got something to eat I took a cab and went to Vine Street . Well , they refused to take me in .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Refused to take you in !

sp.speaker: FRAMPINGTON
sp.p: Would n't even take my name .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: But did you tell them clearly what you 'd done — your crime ?

sp.speaker: FRAMPINGTON
sp.p: I was most explicit .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I suppose it is a crime .

sp.speaker: FRAMPINGTON
sp.p: Oh , yes ! It 's a crime all right . As far as the Bishop and I could make out , it means anything up to three years ; but I must say the episcopal library at Chelmsford is n't very strong in criminal law . It seems to deal chiefly with vegetarianism and drunkenness .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
