sp.p: Brushing all this aside .I may be dull , Mr .——

sp.speaker: FRAMPINGTON
sp.p: Frampington .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: But I do n't yet understand why you 've come here .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Mr. Frampington was going to explain how it was the police-station was so inhospitable .

sp.speaker: FRAMPINGTON
sp.p: The Inspector would n't believe my story . He thought I was a practical joker .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: And do n't you think you are ?

sp.speaker: FRAMPINGTON
sp.p: Judicially .Depends how one looks at it . I feel sure I should have been more convincing if I had n't changed my clothes . But the Bishop insisted on me doing that , and so I put on the only suit I had . And then I found I 'd chosen a bad night . Owing to these vivisection riots , they were doing a big business in medical students at Vine Street . In fact , my suspicion is that all their cells were engaged . And there 's another thing — I do n't think I ought to have gone to Vine Street . Vine Street specialises in what you may call West End cases — pocket-picking , confidence tricks , murder , aristocratic inebriety , and so on . It runs in a groove . But then Vine Street was the only police-station that I was personally acquainted with — a youthful souvenir of Boatrace night — and so I went there . It was a mistake .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: I 'm afraid you did n't insist .

sp.speaker: FRAMPINGTON
sp.p: Yes . I did . I insisted so much that at last the Inspector got cross and said that if I did n't clear he should lock me up .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: And was n't that enough for you , my man ?

sp.speaker: FRAMPINGTON
sp.p: Starting slightly at the appellation .It was too much . I naturally wanted to be locked up for the right thing . The truth is the Inspector thought I was drunk — probably because I was so calm . One of the constables said I — er — smelt of drink .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: And did you ?

lg.l: Certainly not . Beyond half-a-pint of Bordeaux at the
Ritz , I assure you I had had nothing whatever .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: The Ritz ?

sp.speaker: FRAMPINGTON
sp.p: Why not , madam ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: As you say , why not !

sp.speaker: FRAMPINGTON
sp.p: It was handy for Vine Street , and this being my last night of freedom , you see —— As a novelist , Mrs. Haslam , you will understand I had a natural desire to do myself well .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: The only thing I understand is that you seem to have come here for the pleasure of hearing yourself talk .

sp.speaker: FRAMPINGTON
sp.p: Rising simply .I beg your pardon . I came here to ask the Bishop to accompany me to the police-station as corroborative evidence . When your servant told me he was n't here , the idea occurred to me that perhaps some member of your family would n't mind going with me — just to identify me .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Charlie , you 'd better go on your way to the office .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: That 's all very well , but ——

sp.speaker: FRAMPINGTON
sp.p: It would be very good of you . But I really think we ought to try another police-station . Bow Street would be better — more classical — if it is n't too much off your beat .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Why do n't you go to Liverpool Street ?

sp.speaker: FRAMPINGTON
sp.p: But Liverpool Street is not a police-station .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: No . But it 's a railway station . Chelmsford is n't the only place it leads to . There 's Harwich , for instance , the continent ——Smiles .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: In a low voice .Really , Flora ! Christianity can be carried too far .

sp.speaker: FRAMPINGTON
sp.p: To FLORA .I should be caught . And , honestly , I prefer the new experience which lies before me . It can n't last long . And new experiences are my hobby .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: But this is serious . You may n't get a long sentence , but when you 're discharged from prison you 'll be a social outcast .

sp.speaker: FRAMPINGTON
sp.p: Oh , no , I sha n't . In two years time I come into twenty thousand pounds .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I see .

sp.speaker: FRAMPINGTON
sp.p: To CHARLES .May I count on your help ?Bowing adieu to MRS. R. HASLAM .Madam .To FLORA .Mrs. Lloyd , your sympathy is very remarkable , and I appreciate it . Please accept my sincerest apologies for any temporary inconvenience I may have caused you . I assure you , this morning I did n't realise until afterwards the awful seriousness of what I 'd done .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Neither did I . Well , good luck !Shakes hands with him to the deep astonishment of MRS. REACH HASLAM .

div.stage: FRAMPINGTON goes towards door . CHARLES uncertainly goes in the same direction , then stops .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: To FRAMPINGTON .Just wait in the hall a moment , will you ?

sp.speaker: FRAMPINGTON
sp.p: Certainly .Exit back .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Turning to FLORA .Well , it 's not often that I 'm left speechless ——

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Look here , mater . You send me off with this lunatic , but it does n't seem to have occurred to you that I 've had no dinner . I have n't even had time to wash .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Before he has finished .Why did you shake hands with him , dear ? You were almost effusive .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I felt almost effusive .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: But do n't you think he 's off his nut ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Whatever he is , he 's saved me from something that 's rather awful to think about .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: He 's what ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I may as well tell you now — Cedric and I are n't going to get married to-morrow .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Not going to ——stopsBut you 've just arranged with the Bishop !

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I know . But that was simply my cowardice . The truth is I had n't the heart to tell him . I felt that we could express ourselves more comfortably in a telegram than by word of mouth .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: We ! But — but what 's wrong with to-morrow , Flora ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Nothing . It 's no worse than any other day . Only we are n't going to get married at all .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: But you are married — practically . I mean ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Shakes her head .Not even theoretically .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: With a certain dignified appeal .Flora , I 'm not as young as you are . I 'm a hard working woman . My work is terribly in arrear . But I 've never broken a contract yet , and I must finish to-night that article of mine for “ Harper 's ” on “ A Remedy for the Decline of the Birthrate in London Society . ” The subject is delicate for a popular magazine , and I need to have my mind free . May I beg you to tell me exactly what you mean , without being too witty ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I 'm really very sorry . Very sorry . If I 'm witty , I honestly assure you it 's an oversight . All I can tell you is that Cedric and I have had an extremely serious difference of opinion , on a vital matter , and there 's no hope of our views being reconciled , and so we are n't going to get married .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Not really !

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Half to herself .And this is all you can find to do , to help me with my article !To FLORA .I suppose I must imitate your calmness .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Winningly .Oh ! please do .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: When did you and Cedric settle this ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: We have n't settled it . Have we had a moment alone together since we left Pixton ? I 've settled it . One person can settle these things .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Do you mean to say that Cedric does n't know what you 're telling me ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Not unless he 's listening behind the door . I inform you before anyone .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Of course father and I both noticed that you were far from being yourselves . But we put it down to the shock and disappointment .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: To the Frampington accident ? Oh , no ! A Frampington accident might happen to any unmarried couple . I 'm afraid our gloom was caused by nothing but a terrible fear .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Terrible fear ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Terrible fear lest neither of us would have the audacity to profit by Mr. Frampington 's revelation .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Audacity ! Your audacity astounds me .

lg.l: Yes , it rather startles even me . Now , will you mind telling
Cedric ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: I !Looks at her . Then exit , L .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Are you also struck dumb ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: I suppose the kick-up was about — Snowdon versus honeymoon .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Charlie , how penetrating you are , really ! And you put it in a nutshell .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Well , when we burst into that hotel this morning I could have sworn something was wrong . Do n't you remember I enquired what was the matter ? And just now when I was asking Rick what he meant to do , it did n't want any very powerful penetration to see that there must have been a hades of a rumpus between him and you .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Puzzlingly .Oh ! Did n't it ? And what 's your opinion ? Do you think Snowdon ought to win ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Well , it 's fiendishly important .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I know . But do n't you think a honeymoon 's somehow more important ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Some honeymoons might be .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: What should you have done in Cedric 's place ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: But look here , Flo , he has given way , you know .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Yes , but against his judgment .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Well , he could n't help that .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: You 're wrong , Charlie .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Am I ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Could n't help it ? If Cedric can n't control his judgment better than that , in a serious matter , at the very start of the marriage , so much the worse for him and for me .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Perhaps so .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Charlie , there are some things that you understand better than Cedric .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: That 's what I always say , but no one believes me .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: It 's true . Do you know I 'm simply shaking ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Fright ?FLORA nods .I can believe you are , but nobody 'd guess it .

div.stage: Half-enter CEDRIC , L .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Stopping at half-opened door . To somebody outside the room .What 's that you say ?Exit again , leaving door ajar .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: You 'd better go . Do n't forget the imitation curate 's waiting for you .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Frizzle the imitation curate .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: You 'll be in the way here — do n't you see ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: But you 're sending me off just at the interesting part . And you 'll all be gone to bed before I get back from the office .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Yes , but I hope we shall all still be alive to-morrow . Now — there 's a dear , before Cedric comes .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: But — is it really serious ?FLORA nods .Then we sha n't have to go to Chelmsford to-morrow ?FLORA shakes her head .Nor any other day ?FLORA shakes her head . CHARLES moves reluctantly towards the door .Well , I can n't realise it , and that 's flat . I say ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Would you mind telling father or mother to see that my supper is set for me in the garden to-night ? And something solid , too !

div.stage: Enter CEDRIC .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I will .

div.stage: Exit CHARLES , back .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I see your mother 's told you . Well , what can I say to you ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Sitting down .You might congratulate me on the way I 'm keeping calm under stress .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: But why do you come in like this and look at me like this ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Idle curiosity ! Having received the news from the mater , I was absurdly curious to hear any remarks you might have to make to me . So I came in — like this .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Cedric , I did it the best way I could . I thought I would imitate the blandness of the sham curate . You have n't seen him to-night , but I may tell you he carries blandness further than it has ever been carried before .... I was afraid if I did n't do it at once it might never be done . I could see the time going on and going on , and me preparing myself to do this thing in a nice , kind , tactful , proper way , exactly as it should be done — and never doing it — never beginning to do it ! And at last finding myself at Chelmsford to-morrow , and hypnotised by your mother and the Bishop . Cedric , I 'm sure it 's a mistake to prepare to do a thing like this , leading up to it , and so on . The best plan is to let it go off with a frightful bang , anyhow , as I 've done ! Then the worst happens at the start instead of at the finish .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: I quite see the argument .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: With a nod of the head towards the door , L .You 've told her the reason ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: She 'd half guessed it . I made it seem as plausible as I could , in my taciturn way . But you know it would need a course of lectures to explain it properly .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I suppose I ought to depart hence . Where is your mother now ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: She 's briefly stating the facts to the head of the family .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Cedric , do n't you feel as if I 'd lifted an enormous weight off your chest ? Candidly !

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: No ; but I feel as if we 'd been sitting all day in a stuffy railway carriage with a window that would n't open , and there 'd been a collision that had pitched us clean through it . I 've got oxygen , but I 'm dashed if I can feel my legs .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: My dear Cedric , if you were seriously injured you could n't talk like that .

div.stage: Enter , L ., during the last words , MRS. REACH HASLAM and MR. REACH HASLAM , very solemn .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Has Charlie gone ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Yes . By the way , he wants his supper set in the garden — he asked me to tell you .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Thank you .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Something solid , he said .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Sitting down .Cedric , I wish your father to hear for himself exactly what the situation is . I naturally turn to him and leave everything to him .... Now , father .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: So far as I 've gathered , there seems to be some slight difficulty as to dates . To-day 's the 20th — to-morrow will be the 21stlooking at date calendarYes , the 21st . Flora thinks the honeymoon ought to end on the 21st prox ., whereas Cedric thinks the honeymoon ought to end in about ten days ’ time , say 1st prox . The difference of opinionironical stresson this highly important matter , this fundamental matter , is final . Hence Flora has absolutely decided to break off the marriage .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: That 's it .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Nothing could be simpler .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Flora , how can you sit there and trifle with our deepest feelings , in this utterly cynical manner ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Persuasively .I hope we are n't going to converse as if we were characters in a powerful novel of modern society . This is real life , you know , let 's talk as if we were real people — do you mind ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Personally , I am not aware of being unreal . But you seem to be unaware that you are playing with tragic things .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: As I told Cedric in the first act ——

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Staggered beyond measure .In the first act !

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: My dear . I 'm only trying to fall in with your wish to turn this affair into a tragedy . If it is a tragedy , the first act occurred this morning . As I told Cedric this morning , we 've stumbled across a question of vital principle . Is our marriage to be the most important thing in our lives , or is n't it ? If it is , then nothing less than an earthquake could possibly disturb the honeymoon , because I suppose you 'll admit the honeymoon is the most urgent part of matrimony . If our marriage is not to be the most important thing in our lives — all right ! That 's a point of view that I can understand ; only — I do n't want to get married . And I wo n't !Pause .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Cedric , why do n't you speak ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Nothing to say .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Your silence is excessive .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Still persuasively .We solemnly arrange our honeymoon . Then Cedric happens to see a newspaper and he as good as says , “ Here 's something more important than our honeymoon . Our honeymoon must give way to this . ” And after all , this terrific something is nothing whatever but a purely business matter — something to do with the works .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Something to do with England , with Cedric 's career , with Cedric 's duty .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Turning to MR. REACH HASLAM .Supposing Cedric one day said he could n't attend his father 's funeral because his career called him elsewhere , because England wanted him , what should you say ?

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: I probably should n't open my mouth .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: A funeral is different ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: It is . But I can n't help thinking that if circumstances ought n't to prevent a man from going to a funeral , they ought n't to prevent him from going to his own honeymoon .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: I hope you wo n't lose sight of the fact that I gave way to you absolutely about five hours ago .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: That 's the trouble .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Father !

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Yes , that 's the trouble , because his giving way to her is a proof that he did n't share her views . What Flora objects to in Cedric is not what he does , but what he thinks . She seems to me to have no use for free-thinking in a husband .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I wo n't argue any further .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: But why not ? Surely that is unreasonable .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Because in an argument I always begin rather well , but in the end I 'm apt to get beaten . So I just stop , especially when I know I 'm right . I 'm a short distance woman . All I say is — can you imagine me — me , running off to Ostend with a man who had sacrificed his career , and Snowdon , and all England , unwillingly , in order to go ... what gay little suppers we should have together !

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: One day , perhaps when it 's too late , you 'll realise that a wife 's first duty , and therefore her greatest joy , is to help her husband . I know I realised it , at once . When I was married , Reach was only earning three hundred a year ; he was a solicitor 's managing clerk — were n't you , father ? I said to myself that I ought to try to help him , and so I began to write . And as a wife , I 've been doing my best to help him ever since . After ten years I thought it advisable for him to give up the law . How much did I pay income-tax on last year , dear ?

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Nineteen thousand four hundred pounds .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: I do n't boast , but you see what comes of trying to do one 's wifely duty !

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Some women can do nothing but earn money .CEDRIC begins playing mechanically with an object on the table .I can only spend it . Two different talents ! If I had a hundred pounds to throw away at this moment , I know what I should spend it on ——A pause . She looks round ; exerting all her wayward charm .Come , why does n't some one ask me what I should spend it on ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Gloomily perfunctory .What should you spend it on ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I should erect a statue to Mr. Frampington . It would be a good thing if there were a few more Frampingtons about , just to give people who 've got as far as the vestry a chance of reconsidering their position .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Upon my word , Floracuttingly, one would say , from your sparkling wit , that you were quite in high spirits over the situation .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Well , my dear , in one way I could cry my eyes out , but in another I am rather uplifted when I think of what Mr. Frampington has saved us from .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Saved you from !Very courteously and quietly .Really , I should have thought that any woman would have been more than a little flattered at the prospect of marrying into the Haslam family , of being the wife of Cedric . No house in London is more sought after than ours . It is n't too much to say that Cedric is now one of the most celebrated men in England ——

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Crossly .Look here , mater ——He keeps his head down ; he is still playing with the object on the table .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Sharply .Cedric !MRS. REACH HASLAM looks at her husband , as if expecting him majestically to reprove his son .I wish you 'd play with something else for a change .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: I speak kindly , but I speak plainly , and I 'm not ashamed of doing so . I say one of the most celebrated men in England . Indeed , it would n't surprise me to learn that among the masses of the people Cedric is better known even than I am myself .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Mater , I 'm off !

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Severely to him .You 'll kindly stay where you are . There are times when one ought to be frank .Still very courteously and quietly to FLORA .You know I was not at first altogether in favour of this marriage — not what could be described as uncontrollably enthusiastic about it . I have appreciated your excellent qualities , but ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Smiling .Please do n't expose me . Comfort yourself with the thought of what Mr. Frampington has saved you from .

div.stage: MR. REACH HASLAM rises softly and goes towards door , back .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Where are you going , father ?

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: I thought I 'd just make sure about Charlie 's supper , before it slipped my memory .Exit back .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Turning to FLORA again , pained .You are forgetting the terrible scandal that will ensue if you persist in your present course , dear Flora . The honeymoon actually begun ! and then — this bombshell ! How shall we break it to the Bishop ? How can I ever look the Bishop in the face again ! How can I ever look anybody in the face again ?... To-day of all days , when my new book has just come out ! And with my article to finish , on the decline of the birthrate among the well-to-do classes !... How can we explain to people that the marriage is broken off when there 's certain to be an account of the wedding in every paper to-morrow morning ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: That , at any rate , is n't my fault . By-the-way , how did that paragraph get into the “ Piccadilly Gazette ” ?Mischievously .I suppose it must have slipped in while you were looking the other way .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: With controlled acerbity .When you begin to figure prominently in the life of your country , Flora , you 'll understand , perhaps , a little better than you do now that newspaper reporters , whatever their sex , simply will not be denied . They reside on the doorstep . One cannot be rude . At least I can n't .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I hope I never shall figure prominently in the life of my country . But I want to figure prominently in the life of my husband .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: The newspapers ——

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Excuse me , mater , but is n't this right off the point ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: To herself .And I was looking forward to a quiet half hour with my press-cuttings !

div.stage: Silence .
Enter MR. REACH HASLAM cautiously , back .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Mildly cheerful .Well , where have you got to ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I think we 're gradually working back again to the importance of marriage in the life of the husband .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: That 's better ! That 's better !Sits .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Flora , you 'll pardon me offering my opinion , as an experienced student of human nature , but when you say “ the importance of marriage , ” I think you really mean your own individual importance . Personal vanity is very misleading .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Oh ! It is .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Your attitude might be more defensible if you were a different kind of woman . I do n't say it would be more defensible , but it might be .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Oh , look here , mater ——

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Cedric , may I venture to converse in my own study ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: To CEDRIC .Do n't you understand that this is not your act ?Rising .How a different kind of woman ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Quietly courteous .I mean , if you brought more to the marriage .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Money ? I 'm not rich , but you see I 'm rich enough to despise ten thousand pounds .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Protesting .Flora ! Please do n't mention such a thing ! Have I mentioned it ? I think we Haslams are as capable as anybody of despising ten thousand pounds .Very kindly .No , I mean , if you had more to show in the way of — shall I say ?— striking personal talent . You can have no rôle except that of wife , purely social and domestic . And yet your attitude seems somehow to claim the privileges of a — a great singer , or a great pianist , or ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: A great novelist ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Imperturbable .No , no . I was thinking more of public performers .... Genius .... If you had genius , talents . Mind , I 'm not blaming you for not having them . I make no reflection whatever .... Of course you are good , I hope , and you 're beautiful .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: So they say .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: But beauty is a mere gift — from heaven .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: My dear , what 's the difference between a talent , and a gift from heaven ? I remember not very long since you were really quite annoyed because the “ Saturday Review , ” I think it was , referred to you as “ Mrs. Reach Haslam , the talented novelist . ” Whereas you are constantly being called the “ gifted novelist , ” and you like it .She begins to sit down .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Pardon me . “ Like ” is too strong a word . My wife prefers to be mentioned as “ Mrs. Reach Haslam , ” simply — do n't you , dear ? One does n't expect to read in the papers “ Mr. Balfour , the talented statesman , ” “ Lord Northcliffe , the talented statesman . ” One expects only “ Mr. Balfour , ” “ Lord Northcliffe . ”

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Waving him graciously into silence . To FLORA .I willingly admit , dear , that in its origin a talent — like mine , if you insist — is a gift from heaven . But what years of study are necessary to perfect it ! Whereas mere beauty , charm ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Having sat down , and finally arranged her fan and shawl , etc .It 's taken me at least seven years of intense study to learn to sit down like that — and in another two years I shall do it even better .With a delightful smile .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Graciously lenient .But seriously ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Seriously ?Stopping , in a different tone .My dear , did the Bishop say anything when I left the room ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Say anything ! About what ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: About me .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: He remarked that you were a ravishing creature .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Jokingly ?

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: No . He was quite serious .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: That 's just it . If it was only frivolous , empty-headed boys who were serious about it , but it is n't . The most high-minded , middle-aged men are serious about it . Why , even chaffeurs and policemen are serious about it . There must be something in it . Wherever I go people are more serious about me than about anybody else — even if singers and pianists happen to be present . If I arrive late at the theatres I 'm the play for at least two minutes . And I assure you in the streets it often occurs that men I do n't know hurry after me very seriously about it — even if I 'm veiled . And yet you and I have the same dressmaker ! It 's always been like that — ever since my first marriage . And it 's getting more and more marked . I do n't mind telling you , my dear , that my own secret view of my importance is perhaps as modest as yours is of yours — but what can you and I do against the universal opinion ? I 've begin to bow before the storm . It 's the wisest course . You talk about what I bring to the marriageproudlyI bring to the marriage the gift of heaven , cultivated by the labour of a lifetime , and , as to its value , there 's only one estimate , except yourswith a catch in her voice— and Cedric 's ! Cedric puts an aeroplane higher .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: I beg your pardon ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: With emotion .Yes , you do ! Yes , you do ! When there came a conflict between my honeymoon and your aeroplane , you decided instantly against the honeymoon , before I 'd even been asked ! You did n't even consult me .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Aeroplane ! Aeroplane ! You keep on saying aeroplane , but ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Calmer .Listen . I know you 've given way . I know you 've offered not to sacrifice the honeymoon , but do n't you really think still in your own mind that the honeymoon ought to be sacrificed ?CEDRIC does not answer — pause .You know perfectly well it 's a relief to you that I 've cried off ! Come , honestly now ?

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Warningly , under his breath .Not too honestly .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Quietly .Yes , I do think part of the honeymoon ought to be sacrificed . And I never dreamed that you would think otherwise . It 's a difference of opinion that simply staggers me . It does n't only stagger me — it frightens me . It makes one reflect , you know .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Then you are relieved ? You 're grateful .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Moved and stammering .I ought to be . Of course you 're the only person who could cry off .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Some things a man can n't do .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Do you sit there and say that if I had n't cut the knot , you 'd have gone on , and you 'd have let me go on , with a marriage you did n't believe in ? Because you 're a man , and there are some things a man can n't do ! Ca n't a man show as much pluck as a woman ? That does settle it !Controlling herself .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Flora , you 'll regret you 've thrown Cedric over . You 'll certainly want to come back to him .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Disdainfully .Shall I !Politely .Good-night , Mrs. Haslam .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: But where are you going ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I do n't know . How can I stay here ? My official connection with this house is ended . I shall go to a hotel . Good-night . So many thanks !

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Rising and going to her ; firmly .I 'm sure you 'll oblige me by not scandalising the servants . You can choose a hotel to-morrow morning . I 'll go with you to your room , if I may . All your trunks will be up there by this time .

div.stage: Exeunt FLORA , submissive , and MRS. REACH HASLAM , back .
MR. REACH HASLAM slowly prepares for work at desk .

lg.l: I 'm off into the garden .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Aside as CEDRIC goes .Nincompoop !

div.stage: Enter MRS. REACH HASLAM .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Dear , before I go on with that article , I should like to make a few notes on Flora 's demeanour , while the thing 's fresh in my mind . One never knows when that kind of stuff wo n't come in useful .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Where 's the boy ?

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: In the garden .Half to himself .Of all places !

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Collecting her thoughts and beginning to dictate .“ Essentially hysterical in a crisis , but does not pull a face before weeping , probably owing to advice from toilette specialist . ” Yes , full stop .

div.stage: CURTAIN .

div.head: ACT III .

stage.stage: Garden of the REACH HASLAMS ’ house in Palace Gardens . House front to the left . At the back , shrubberies and trees . In centre , an arbour or pergola , with the open side to the footlights . Under the shelter of this a table , with remains of a meal .

div.stage: TIME : Next morning 4 a. m . Magnificent sunrise . CEDRIC is sitting at the table , having finished eating . He is still in evening dress , and dishevelled .
Enter CHARLES through shrubberies from back . He wears the same costume as in previous act , with hat , stick , etc .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Hello ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: So you 're here , are you ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Wiping his mouth .I am .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Well , what 's happened ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: What do I mean ? You and Flora , of course !

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Nothing more .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Then is it off ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: With a nervous laugh .Right bang off !Pause .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: You look as if you 'd been up all night .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Nods .What time is it ? My watch has stopped .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: About four . I 'm a trifle late .Sits down to table .Well , my boy , I 've got a bit of news for you . I do n't know whether it 'll influence you , but ——startledLook here , have you been eating my supper ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Was it for you ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: I must say this really is a bit too thick !

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: How should I know it was for you ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Of course you knew !

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: It was all laid here . The fact is , I went off to sleep . I must have slept solid for about four hours . When I woke up just now , I was as hungry as a dog , so I just — I never thought ——

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Never thought be damned !

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Awfully sorry . Here 's some bread . What 's this news ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Taking bread .What 's the good of being sorry ? It was entirely on account of you I had no tea yesterday and no dinner either , and now I 'm dashed if you have n't gone and eaten my supper too !

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: What 's this news ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Eating .If I had n't had some sultana at the office I do n't know what I should have done . I 've a good mind not to tell you !Taking paper from his pocket .Here ! This is a second edition , just off the machinesopening paperOh , curse ! Mind the ink !Looking at his hands , after giving paper to CEDRIC , who examines it .There you are !indicating a paragraph in the paper

div.stage: CEDRIC reads , then rises .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: After reflection .See here , boy . You just go to bed out of the way and do n't ever let on that you 've shown me this paper or even knew what there was in it . Do you hear ?Putting paper in his pocket .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: I hear . But why ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Never mind why .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: But the newsagent will deliver the mater 's copy here at eight o'clock , and by half-past eight you may bet everybody in the place ——

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: I 'm going to do something long before eight o'clock .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: What are you going to do ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: I 'm going to see Flora , and tell her I 've altered my view completely . If she knew I 'd seen the paper she 'd be bound to think I 'd only come round because of that , and she would n't listen to me — do n't you see , idiot ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: I see . But have n't you altered your view because of that ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Coldly .What 's that got to do with you ? The point is that at any rate I can go honeymooning now with a free mind . That 's the point .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: And do you reckon all this 'll be on the straight ?

lg.l: I do n't care whether it 's on the straight or not .
I 've got to have that woman — confound her ! and
I 'm going to .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Where is she ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: She 's in the spare room next to the mater 's .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: And how do you intend to get at her ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: I 'm going to call her , and ask her to dress and come down at once . Then I shall talk to her , here . With a bit of luck I may be off with her and on the way to Colchester at six o'clock . Is there plenty of petrol in the stable ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Yes . I say — it 's not right , you know !

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Shut up .Going .Did Fisher clean the car last night ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: How do I know ? He ought to have done . I say ——

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Stopping .Well ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: I suppose you do n't want any advice from me ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: No .Turns and stops again .What ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: I was only going to say that you 'd better change those clothes and make yourself look less of an absolute waster .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Well , of course ! I expect I can dress quicker than she can , can n't I ? I 've thought of all that .

div.stage: He turns finally to leave .
Enter FLORA from house , meeting him . She is fully dressed in morning street attire , and carries a handbag .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Staggered .Good morning !

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Staggered .Good morning !

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Hello , Flo ! What 's the meaning of this ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Could n't sleep .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Hastily and nervously .I shall be down in two jiffs .Aside to CHARLES .See you do n't let her go .Exit into house .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I guessed you 'd be having your supper just about now . That 's why I came down here .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Pleased .That 's fine . Only I 'm not having my supper . Cedric 's eaten it all . He 's been out here all night , and he 's eaten it all — except thisshowing bread

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: My poor boy ! But here 's a couple of bananas . Have you ever tried banana sandwiches ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: No . Are they any good ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Are they any good ! Never had a banana sandwich ! Shall I make you some ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: I wish you would .Silence , while she sets about sandwiches .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Well , how long shall I have to wait ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Wait ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: To hear what happened to Mr. Frampington , of course . Did they take him in at Bow Street ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Oh , yes .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Do you know — I 'm rather sorry . Somehow I should have liked him to get clear away . Here !Gives him a sandwich , which he eats . Then solemnlyNow , Charlie , I 'm going . I want to be gone before anybody 's up .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: What occurred last night ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Oh ! terrific scenes ! terrific scenes ! and I really can n't face your mother this morning at breakfast . I could n't do it . And it 's quite unnecessary . So I 'm going to the Great Western Hotel . I shall pretend I 've arrived by a night train . And I want you to see that my trunks are brought there later . Here !Gives him another sandwich .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: All serene ! Thanks !After thought .I say — I rather like Frampington , too .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: I do n't know . It 's due to him — somehow — I feel like you feel .... I say , Flora , has it ever occurred to you that I 'm a mere cipher in this house ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Really ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: I 'm nobody . I 'm pitched about everywhere .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: You do n't mean — my trunks ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Not a bit . Of course I do n't . I mean the way they treat me . Here Cedric 's a perfect duke , in his own line . But will he have me on the works ? Not much . Says I must strike out for myself , and all sorts of tommyrot . And in the end I 'm set to night-work like a blooming nigger . People might think we were hard up for five quid a week , instead of simply rolling in coin — rolling in it ! Why should n't I go round the world or something ! I 'm only twenty-two .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: That all ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: I go out and work all night . Then I come home and discover Cedric could n't find anything better to do than eat my supper . Five servants in this house . But do you suppose there 'd have been the least chance of me getting anything to eat before eight o'clock , at the earliest , if you had n't invented these sandwiches ? Not much ! Thanks !Takes two more .But that 's not what I meant . What I really meant was — who introduced my people to you ? I did . I knew you at the Baths Club six months before his lordship Cedric and the mater kindly invited themselves to have tea with me there , and then I did n't count any more ! Cedric simply shovelled me up and chucked me into a corner . In less than twenty-four hours he was in love with you . But did he ask my permission ? Did he think about me for one instant ? Not much ! The fact is , they simply make use of me ... and so — I rather like Frampington . Understand ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Of course , I 'm sorry about what 's happened — as far as you are concerned . But as far as Cedric 's concerned , I can n't help thinking it serves him jolly well right . Cedric 's too cocksure — in everything .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: That 's quite true .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Hesitating .Yes .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: What else have you got on your mind ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Well , I do n't know if I ought to tell you .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Certainly you ought to tell me .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: You think so ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Unless , of course , you agree with all the things your dear mother 's been saying to me .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: It 's about Klopstock .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: About Klopstock ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: He 's had an accident .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Broken his leg .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: How ? Came down too quickly ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: No . Driving to his hotel last night his motor ran into a statue of Bismarck , and he was thrown out .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Motor cars are really too dangerous . I wonder any aviator cares to trust himself to them .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Admiringly .Now it 's very funny . I often want to say things like that , only I can never think of them . Cedric — he can come out with them sometimes , and so can the dad . But you 're the only woman I ever struck that could .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Charlie , you 're a dear . I suppose he 'll be laid up for five or six weeks .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Who ? Klopstock ? You bet . You see what it means ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Quite . What I do n't see is why you should have hesitated to tell me about it . I suppose you 've told Cedric ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Yes . I brought an early copy of the paper with it in .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Where is it ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Cedric 's cleared off with it .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Well , if Cedric knows , why should n't I ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Ask me another ! Look here , I 'm giving the show away , but I 've got my conscience to think of . This is a serious matter . I mean — really serious ! I do n't like it , but it 's my duty to warn you .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Cedric told me I was n't to say a word . He said I was n't to let on that I 'd told him .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: And did you promise ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: I should think I did n't . Not me !

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Had Cedric been out here all night ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Yes . Told me he slept like a top in that chair , then woke up and ate my supper .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: But why should he want you not to say anything about Klopstock ?Enter CEDRIC , in a lounge suit , somewhat awry , with a hat . FLORA continues in the same tone to CHARLES .Here , have this last oneoffering him another sandwich . To CEDRICIt appears you 've been eating what does n't belong to you . So I 've done my best with bananas and stale bread to fill the breach .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Nervous .You 've forgotten your hair , my boy .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: With a gesture ; low to CHARLES .Hook it !He repeats the gesture .

div.stage: Exit CHARLES unwillingly , into house .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Primly .I 'm just going . I meant to leave before any of you were up . I thought that would be the wisest thing to do . But Charles begged me to stop and look after him a bit .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: What 's he been entertaining you with ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Oh ! his grievances . They 're rather real , you know .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Do you know , when I went in just now I was meaning to knock at your door and ask you to get up at once . Curious thing , that you should have been coming downstairs at that very moment !

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Why this desire to begin the day so early ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Look here , Flora , let 's go , now ! Fisher wo n't be up , but the car 's cleaned and there 's plenty of petrol . Come on . Just you and I .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Innocently .Where ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Chelmsford . I can wake the Bishop and tell him we want the job done at eight o'clock instead of twelve . Any old verger and charwoman will do for witnesses . The thing will be all over before the mater 's out of bed . We can telephone to ‘ em from Chelmsford with the pleasing news .Pause . As FLORA says nothing , he continues , rather less confidently .It 'll give ‘ em an appetite for breakfast .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Ironically .Any other details ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: With rough persuasiveness .Come on !

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Ironically .Then you 've decided that we are to get married , after all ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Well , a marriage can n't be broken off like — like this ! It 's unthinkable . What would any unprejudiced outsider say , if he was asked ? He 'd say we were off our blooming heads . The thing simply wo n't bear examination .Moves towards her .Come ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: And I 'm to be carried by storm ?.... Great saving of argument !

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Now listen ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Will you talk man to man ? Straight ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: As one honest Injun to another !

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Picking up a dish off the table .If you make one more joke , I 'll smash every darned bit of crockery on this table .Gesture of destruction .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Coldly .Now if I agree to listen quietly and talk reasonably , it must n't be understood that I 'm open to argument .Sits down .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: All right , all right !

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Because I 'm not . I 'm not . I 'm not . The thing that 's — that 's really upset our applecart may seem perfectly childish to the unprejudiced outsider . But I do n't propose to consult the unprejudiced outsider . Might as well take the case before a jury and engage a couple of K. C .' s . You know as well as I know that it is n't perfectly childish . It is n't childish at all . Its fundamental . We 've been unlucky . But then in another sense we 've been lucky . We 're free . We are n't tied , thank Heaven . Man to man , Cedric , it would be too much humiliation — yes , humiliation — for me to marry anybody that looks on marriage as you look on it . And as it 's just as impossible for you to change your opinion as it is for me to change mine , we sha n't exactly go down to Colchester this morning .... More 's the pity .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Well , I have changed my opinion . So let 's go .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: You 've changed your opinion ? How have you changed your opinion ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: I 've sat there all this blessed night thinking it over .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Really ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Yes . Do you suppose I could sleep any more than you could ? What do you take me for ? The more I thought it over , the more I saw I 'd been mistaken . Now — half a minute ! I can n't honestly blame myself , you know . And so I wo n't pretend to — especially as we 're talking straight . I told you what I felt , right out , and then I offered to give way . I could n't do anything else . Well , you would n't have that . Mind you , I think you were quite right in refusing to let me give way against my better judgment . I admire you for that even more than I did . But I do n't give way now against my judgment — I give way with it .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: But how has your judgment altered ? Why ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: I do n't know . How do people 's judgments alter ? I gradually saw the force of what you 'd said . Of course a man 's marriage must come in front of everything else ! Of course the idea of letting any business matter interfere with the honeymoon is monstrous ! I cannot imagine how it was I could n't see that yesterday . The only explanation is that up to yesterday I 'd never lived for anything except my job . Force of habit ! One has to get a bit used to a new state of affairs . I suppose it was the sudden shock of the news that sent me a bit off the track . Look here , Flora , you do n't want me to go on in this strain . You do n't want me to grovel . I 'm not the grovelling sort ... I was mistaken .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: In a new quiet tone .Cedric , what happened in your mother 's study after I went upstairs last night ?

lg.l: Nothing whatever . I cleared out instantly afterwards .
I 've been here ever since , and I have n't spoken to a soul except
Charlie . Why ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Nothing .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: But why do you say “ Nothing ” like that ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Cedric , I was just wondering how this conversation of yours really did come about . It occurred to me that perhaps something might have happened — in business ——

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Nervous .How — “ something ” — in business ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Something — I do n't know — something that would leave you free after all for a full month , so that in being converted you would n't have to sacrifice anything at all .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: But how could anything have happened ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I do n't know , but with that telephone so handy in your mother 's study —— All manner of things happen nowadays over the telephone — especially in the middle of the night .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Relieved . Affecting a cheerful irony .What notions she does get into her head ! My dear girl , nothing whatever has happened — so far as I know . Of course nothing could . My conversion , as you call it , is due simply and solely to my thinking things over .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Honour bright ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Firmly .Certainly !... Then you really imagined I was capable of such a — you could n't trust me ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: It is n't you I could n't trust . It 's the human nature in you that I had my doubts about . It 's always so apt to get the better of people , and make them play tricks they 'd never dream of by themselves .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Shocked but forgiving .Fluff !

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Somewhat coldly .I 'm only being man to man .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Look here , Flora , it 's barely twelve hours since that vulgar idiot Klopstock shoved himself into our honeymoon . Barely twelve hours . We were in love with each other up till then , were n't we ?Silence .Were n't we ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Primly .Yes .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Very much ?Silence .I say very much ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: More primly .Yes .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Well , if you know as much about human nature as you make out , you know perfectly well that we must still be very much in love with each other . I mean now , here ! Anyone might think , to hear some of the talk that went on last night , and even to see us at this moment , that we did n't care twopence for each other . But a passion wo n't be knocked on the head like that . You can n't get over it — we 're still damnably in love . We 've had a row — good ! It 's been an infernal nuisance — good ! I 've been an ass , if you like — good ! And what then ? You 're in love with a man who 's been an ass — that 's all . But you are in love with him . Moreover , he 's ceased to be an ass !... Now , Flora , one ass is enough . Are you going to listen to reason or not ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: But your mother ——

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Picking up a piece of crockery and dashing it violently to the ground ; then , controlling himself , after a pause , in a low , tense voice .My mother be blowed !

div.stage: A pause . MR. and MRS. REACH HASLAM appear at the house-door . They show surprise at the spectacle of FLORA and CEDRIC with an appealing undecided gesture .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Advancing to meet CEDRIC .Cedric !

div.stage: FLORA suddenly perceives MR. and MRS. REACH HASLAM and completely changes her attitude , going towards them .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Really ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Lightly .So we 've all got up with the sparrows !

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: No . These two particular sparrows have just come out for a breath of air before retiring to their nest for the day .Yawns .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Work is work , young lady , and insists on being donewith meaning, whatever else happens or does not happen .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Ah ! The birthrate article — has the poor thing been declining all this time ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Anxious for his parents to depart .Mother , you ought to go to bed at once — you look absolutely exhausted .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Is it surprising ? I was just saying to your father that if this kind of thing was likely to occur often I should have to devise some way of procuring tea at sunrise .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: But do you want some tea ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: I never want what I can n't have . I shall doubtless hold out till eight o'clock .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Could n't the dad make you some ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Impossible , child ! At four o'clock in the morning !

lg.l: The cook always locks up the kitchen to keep
Cuthbert and Fisher out .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Seems odd that in a house like this you can n't have a cup of tea whenever you happen to want it !

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Coldly resenting this criticism of her housekeeping .Father , shall we go ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: May I give you some tea ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: It 's very good of you to offer me tea in my own garden , but ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: With great charm .Not at all .Opening her bag .I have my Thermos . I filled it yesterday before starting . You see , we had no programme , and I did n't know where we might ultimately be landed . Besides , I never travel without it .She unscrews the Thermos flask and pours out the steaming tea into the patent cover . Then undoes a little packet containing sugar .One lump , is n't it ?Handing the cup , with a spoon , to MRS. REACH HASLAM , who accepts it .Sit down and drink it . I guessed about forty places where I might pour that tea out — and they were all wrong !MRS. REACH HASLAM discovers that the tea is scalding .It is hot , is n't it ?

lg.l: I 'm afraid you did n't sleep very well ,
Flora .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: You 're down so exceedingly early .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: The fact is , I could not get off to sleep .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Half to himself .I put a complete set of my wife 's novels in each of the spare bedrooms only yesterday .With a faint air of being puzzled .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Another cup ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: No , thanks . Excellent .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I 'm so glad I was here . You know , it 's quite easy to have tea at any hour of the night . But of course , with all your other work , you can n't be troubled with the little details of housekeeping .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Nettled .My other work !... No doubt when you 're settled down with Cedric you will be able to show him what true housekeeping really is .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Settled down with Cedric !

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: My dear , I had intended to make no comment on the singular coincidence of you and Cedric being here in the garden at four in the morning . I did not mean to inquire into the significance of this broken crockery , nor of your attitude and tone to Cedric before you caught sight of me . But I am a trained observer . You may remember that last night ——

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Mater , why do n't you go to bed ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: You may remember that last night I hinted that before very long you 'd probably be throwing yourself into Cedric 's armsbenevolentlyAnd I 'm delighted to see that pride has not stood in your way . Delighted ! How you got him down here into the garden I do n't know , and it does n't matter .Slight pause .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: To CEDRIC .Anything to say ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: You 're quite wrong , mother . The fact is I 've now come to the conclusion that Flora was perfectly right last night .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: About what ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: In arguing that nothing ought to stand in the way of the honeymoon . And I 've just been telling her so .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: But he forgot to tell me that there is nothing now to stand in the way of the honeymoon .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Klopstock has broken his leg and can n't move for at least six weeks .Startled movement by CEDRIC . Quietly gracious , to CEDRIC .Did n't you know ?Silence .Cedric , did n't you know ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: With gruff reluctance .Yes ... of course , Charlie gave me away ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Charlie merely told me , as he told you .

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Everything is all right , then .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Do you think so ? Cedric and I were supposed to be talking like honest Injuns ——

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Honest Injuns ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Well , as man to man , then . Anyway , straight ! And yet he positively assured me that nothing had happened , to influence him except my arguments . Whereas the fact was he knew that owing to this broken leg he could go away with a perfectly easy conscience . My arguments had n't influenced him at all . His principles have n't really changed at all ! But now he 's safe as regards Klopstock he does n't care a fig for his principles . His mind is free for pleasure , now — it was n't before — and so in order to enjoy himself for a month he 'd sacrifice any principles . Just like a man , that is ! And there 's something else . He was so desperately and madly anxious to have me that he told another simply appalling cold-blooded fib . He said he had sat up all through the night thinking over my arguments , without a wink of sleep . I suppose he thought that would touch me . Now the truth is that he slept very well , and woke up with such an appetite that he ate the whole of Charlie 's supper except two bananas . I wo n't mention his references to his mother . But I think I 've said enough to show that I did n't come down at four o'clock in the morning precisely in order to throw myself into your son 's arms . Can you imagine a woman silly enough to marry a man who on the very day of the wedding would try to deceive her as Cedric has tried to deceive me ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Majestic .Father ! We had better go .She moves towards house . After reflection , savagely to FLORA , over her shoulder .I rejoice that the breach is now definite .

div.stage: Exit into house .
CEDRIC moodily goes up garden out of sight .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Protesting .Hannah !Half to himself , looking at his watch .An inflammable hour — four o'clock !

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: We seem to be left alone together .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Cheerfully .Yes , but I must go .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: However do you manage to be always so calm and cheerful ? I 've noticed you in the most difficult situations ——

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: You have .... You see I 've my own private life to fall back on .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Interested .Have you ? Where ? I never ——

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Tapping his forehead .Here !

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I see .

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: And my collection — that always keeps me amused .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Your collection ?

sp.speaker: MR. R. HASLAM
sp.p: My collection of private opinionstapping his headHere , too !

sp.speaker: MRS. R. HASLAM
sp.p: Off .Father !

lg.l: Yes , my dear .
Au revoir , I hope .

div.stage: Exit into house .
Vague noise of CEDRIC privately cursing behind , out of sight .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Going up a little .Cedric , when you 've done swearing up there , I want to apologise to you .

div.stage: Re-enter CEDRIC . They look at each other .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Apologise ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: My human nature ran away with me . My human nature could n't resist the temptation to fulfil your prayer . You demanded that your mother should be blowed — and she has been . Unfortunately it meant you being blowed , too . Now let 's go .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Go where ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Innocently .To Chelmsford , of course . Is n't there a newspaper train about a quarter past five ?

lg.stage: Shaking his head in a maze .
lg.l: I 'm dashed if I know where
I am ——

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: I 'm dashed if you are quite wide awake , my poor boy . Ca n't you see how amply you 've proved that you look on marriage as seriously as any woman could desire — more seriously than any woman ought to desire . Last night you hesitated to sacrifice your aeroplane to me . But this morning you tell the most frightful lies on the chance of getting hold of me — although I gave you every encouragement to be truthful . You take the most frightful risks of being found out . You 'll run any danger of trouble and unhappiness in the future if only you can capture me now . You smash crockery . You behave meanly , miserably . You forfeit even your own self-respect . Cedric , that is what I like . It 's just that that shows how much in earnest you are . Your deeds are far superior to your arguments .... Cedric ——

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: After all , your dear mother 's prophecy was quite correct . I was just going to throw myself into your arms — but of course I could n't do it while she was there , could I ?Picks up Thermos cup , to screw it on to the flask , holding it at arm 's length .Henceforth , sacred !

div.stage: CEDRIC roughly seizes her and kisses her .
After freeing herself , as she puts the flask in the bag . ) It 's a good thing I like them rough .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: A man — and his chin .

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: Snatching at the bag and looking at his watch .Let 's go out by the garden .... Probably find a cab . Motor would make too much noise , and rouse the mater . She 'll never get over this .

sp.speaker: FLORA
sp.p: Calmly .Oh yes , she will . We all shall .Stops .But my trunks , and yours ?

sp.speaker: CEDRIC
sp.p: I 'll wire to Charlie from Liverpool Street to bring them down .... Confound him ! CURTAIN .
